[The girl]3739-the girl was bent on ruining [her]3739-the girl life with these wild notions . [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley decided that it would be better to talk to [Hadria]211-hadria quietly in [[her]141-miss temperley own room]4569-her own room , away from the influence of [these eccentric brothers]4570-these eccentric brothers and [that extraordinary sister]4571-that extraordinary sister . After all , it was [Algitha]81-algitha who had originated the shocking view , not [Hadria]211-hadria , who had merely agreed , doubtless out of a desire to support [[her]141-miss temperley sister]313-her sister . “[0-i] [I]0-i have not known [you]1304-you for seven years , but [I]0-i am going to poke [your]1304-you fire , ” said [Henriette]142-henriette , when [they]4573-they were established in [[Hadria]211-hadria 's room]3863-hadria 's room . “[0-i] [I]0-i never thought [you]0-i would wait so long as that , ” was [Hadria]211-hadria 's ambiguous reply . Then [Henriette]142-henriette opened [her]142-henriette batteries . [She]142-henriette talked without interruption , [[her]142-henriette companion]3995-her companion listening , agreeing occasionally with [[her]142-henriette adversary]4576-her adversary , in a disconcerting manner ; then falling into silence . “[0-i] It seems to [me]0-i that [you]0-i are making a very terrible mistake in [your]0-i life , [Hadria]211-hadria . [You]0-i have taken up a fixed idea about domestic duties and all that , and are going to throw away [your]0-i chances of forming [a happy home of [your]0-i own]1305-a happy home of your own , out of a mere prejudice . [You]0-i may not admire [Mrs. Gordon]91-mrs. gordon 's existence ; for [my]0-i part [I]0-i think [she]91-mrs. gordon leads a very good , useful life , but there is no reason why all married lives should be like [hers]91-mrs. gordon . ” “[91-mrs. gordon] Why are [they]1306-they , then ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i do n't see that [they]1306-they are . ” “[0-i] It is the prevailing type . It shows the why the domestic wind blows . Fancy having to be always resisting such a wind . What [an oblique , shorn - looking object one]1307-an oblique , shorn - looking object one would be after a few years ! ” [Henriette]142-henriette grew eloquent . [She]142-henriette recalled instances of women who had fulfilled all [their]1306-they home duties , and been successful in other walks as well ; [she]142-henriette drew pictures in attractive colours of [Hadria]211-hadria in [a home of [her]211-hadria own]4577-a home of her own , with far more liberty than was possible under [[her]211-hadria parents]3931-her parents ' roof : and then [she]142-henriette drew another picture of [Hadria]211-hadria fifteen years hence at [Dunaghee]1-dunaghee . [Hadria]211-hadria covered [her]211-hadria face with [her]211-hadria hands . “[0-i] [You]0-i who uphold all these social arrangements , how do [you]0-i feel when [you]0-i find [yourself]0-i obliged to urge [me]0-i to marry , not for the sake of the positive joys of domestic existence , but for the merely negative advantage of avoiding a hapless and forlorn state ? [You]0-i propose it as a pis - aller . Does that argue that all is sound in the state of [Denmark]20-denmark ? ” “[0-i] If [you]0-i had not this unreasonable objection to what is really [a woman]3753-a woman 's natural destiny , the difficulty would not exist . ” “[0-i] Have [women]606-women no pride ? ” [Henriette]142-henriette did not answer . “[0-i] Have [they]606-women no sense of dignity ? If [one]329-one marries ( accepting things on the usual basis , of course ) [one]329-one gives to [another person]1312-another person rights and powers over [one]329-one 's life that are practically boundless . To retain [one]329-one 's self - direction in case of dispute would be possible only on pain of social ruin . [I]0-i have little enough freedom now , heaven knows ; but if [I]0-i married , why [my]0-i very thoughts would become the property of [another]1315-another . Thought , emotion , love itself , must pass under the yoke ! There would be no nook or corner entirely and indisputably [my]0-i own . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i should not regard that as a hardship , ” said [Henriette]142-henriette , “[0-i] if [I]0-i loved [[my]0-i husband]1295-my husband . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i should consider it not only a hardship , but beyond endurance . ” “[0-i] But , [[my]0-i dear]3722-my dear , [you]3722-my dear are impracticable . ” “[3722-my dear] That is what [I]0-i think domestic life is ! ” [Hadria]211-hadria 's quiet tone was suddenly changed to one of scorn . “[3722-my dear] [You]3722-my dear talk of love ; what has love worthy of the name to do with this preposterous interference with the freedom of [another person]1312-another person ? If that is what love means — the craving to possess and restrain and demand and hamper and absorb , and generally make mince - meat of [the beloved object]1319-the beloved object , then preserve [me]0-i from the master - passion . ” [Henriette]142-henriette was baffled . “[0-i] [I]0-i do n't know how to make [you]3722-my dear see this in a truer light , ” [she]0-i said . “[3722-my dear] There is something to [my]0-i mind so beautiful in the close union of [two human beings]1320-two human beings , who pledge [themselves]1320-two human beings to love and honour [one another]3945-one another , to face life hand in hand , to share every thought , every hope , to renounce each [his]1295-my husband own wishes for the sake of the other . ” “[3722-my dear] That sounds very elevating ; in practice it breeds [Mr.]1322-mr. and [Mrs. Gordon]91-mrs. gordon . ” “[91-mrs. gordon] Do [you]3722-my dear mean to tell [me]0-i [you]3722-my dear will never marry on this account ? ” “[3722-my dear] [I]0-i would never marry [anyone who would exact the usual submissions and renunciations , or even desire them]1323-anyone who would exact the usual submissions and renunciations , or even desire them , which [I]0-i suppose amounts almost to saying that [I]0-i shall never marry at all . What [man]332-man would endure [a wife who demanded to retain [her]1325-a wife who demanded to retain her absolute freedom , as in the case of a close friendship absolute freedom , as in the case of a close friendship]1325-a wife who demanded to retain her absolute freedom , as in the case of a close friendship ? [The man]3754-the man is not born ! ” “[3722-my dear] [You]3722-my dear seem to forget , [dear [Hadria]211-hadria]1327-dear hadria , in objecting to place [yourself]3722-my dear under the yoke , as [you]3722-my dear call it , that [[your]3722-my dear husband]1288-your husband would also be obliged to resign part of [his]1288-your husband independence to [you]3722-my dear . The prospect of loss of liberty in marriage often prevents [a man]3704-a man from marrying ( [“ Wise man]4579-“ wise man ! ”[211-hadria] ejaculated [Hadria]211-hadria ) , so [you]3722-my dear see the disadvantage is not all on one side , if so [you]3722-my dear choose to consider it . ” “[3722-my dear] Good heavens ! do [you]3722-my dear think that the opportunity to interfere with [another person]1312-another person would console [me]0-i for being interfered with [myself]0-i ? [I]0-i do n't want [my]0-i share of the constraining power . [I]0-i would as soon accept the lash of [a slave - driver]1331-a slave - driver . This moral lash is almost more odious than the other , for its thongs are made of the affections and the domestic ‘ virtues , ’ than which there can be nothing sneakier or more detestable ! ” [Henriette]142-henriette heaved a discouraged sigh . “[3722-my dear] [You]3722-my dear are wrong , [[my]0-i dear]3722-my dear [Hadria]211-hadria , ” [she]0-i said emphatically ; “[3722-my dear] [you]3722-my dear are wrong , wrong , wrong . ” “[3722-my dear] How ? why ? ” “[3722-my dear] One ca n't have everything in this life . [You]3722-my dear must be willing to resign part of [your]3722-my dear privileges for the sake of the far greater privileges that [you]3722-my dear acquire . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i can imagine nothing that would compensate for the loss of freedom , the right to [oneself]1333-oneself . ” “[0-i] What about love ? ” murmured [Henriette]142-henriette . “[0-i] Love ! ” echoed [Hadria]211-hadria scornfully . “[0-i] Do [you]3722-my dear suppose [I]0-i could ever love [a man who had the paltry , ungenerous instinct to enchain [me]0-i]1334-a man who had the paltry , ungenerous instinct to enchain me ? ” “[1334-a man who had the paltry , ungenerous instinct to enchain me] Why use such extreme terms ? Love does not enchain . ” “[0-i] Exactly what [I]0-i contend , ” interrupted [Hadria]211-hadria . “[0-i] But naturally [husband]1286-husband and [wife]1287-wife have claims . ” “[1287-wife] Naturally . [I]0-i have just been objecting to [them]1337-them in what [you]3722-my dear describe as extreme terms . ” “[0-i] But [I]0-i mean , when [people]3687-people care for [one another]3945-one another , it is a joy to [them]3687-people to acknowledge ties and obligations of affection . ” “[0-i] Ah ! [one]329-one knows what that euphemism means ! ” “[329-one] Pray what does it mean ? ” “[329-one] That the one serious endeavour in the life of [married people]1341-married people is to be able to call [each other]4561-each other 's souls [their]4561-each other own . ” [Henriette]142-henriette stared . “[0-i] [My]0-i language may not be limpid . ” “[0-i] Oh , [I]0-i see what [you]3722-my dear mean . [I]0-i was only wondering who can have taught [you]3722-my dear all these strange ideas . ” [Hadria]211-hadria at length gave way to a laugh that had been threatening for some time . “[4254-my mother] [[My]0-i mother]4254-my mother , ” [she]211-hadria observed simply . [Henriette]142-henriette gave it up . [THE family]360-the family had reassembled for the New Year 's festivities . The change in [Algitha]81-algitha since [her]211-hadria departure from [home]3770-home was striking . [She]211-hadria was gentler , more affectionate to [[her]211-hadria parents]3931-her parents , than of yore . The tendency to grow hard and fretful had entirely disappeared . The sense of self was obviously lessened with the need for self - defence . [Hadria]211-hadria discovered that an attachment was springing up between [[her]211-hadria sister]313-her sister and [Wilfred Burton]107-wilfred burton , about whom [she]211-hadria wrote so frequently , and that this development of [her]211-hadria emotional nature , united with [her]211-hadria work , had given a glowing centre to [her]211-hadria life which showed itself in a thousand little changes of manner and thought . [Hadria]211-hadria told [[her]211-hadria sister]313-her sister that [she]0-i felt [herself]0-i unreal and fanciful in [her]0-i presence . “[4254-my mother] [I]0-i go twirling things round and round in [my]0-i head till [I]0-i grow dizzy . But [you]1344-you compare ideas with fact ; [you]1344-you even turn ideas into fact ; while [I]0-i can get no hold on fact at all . Thoughts rise as mists rise from [the river]437-the river , but nothing happens . [I]0-i feel [them]1346-them begin to prey upon [me]0-i , working inwards . ” [Algitha]81-algitha shook [her]81-algitha head . “[1346-them] It is [a mad world]1347-a mad world , ” [she]81-algitha said . “[1346-them] Week after week goes by , and there seems no lifting of the awful darkness in which the lives of [these millions]1348-these millions are passed . [We]1349-we want [workers]1350-workers by [the thousand]1351-the thousand . Yet , as if in mockery , [the Devil]1352-the devil keeps [these well - fed thousands]1353-these well - fed thousands eating [their]1353-these well - fed thousands hearts out in idleness or artificial occupations till [they]1353-these well - fed thousands become diseased merely for want of something to do . Then , ” added [Algitha]81-algitha , “[1352-the devil] [[His]1352-the devil Majesty]1354-his majesty marries [them]1353-these well - fed thousands , and sets [them]1353-these well - fed thousands to work to create another houseful of idle creatures , who have to be supported by the deathly toil of those who labour too much . ” “[1352-the devil] [The devil]1352-the devil is full of resources ! ” said [Hadria]211-hadria . [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley had been asked to stay at [Dunaghee]1-dunaghee for the New Year . [Algitha]81-algitha conceived for [her]141-miss temperley a sentiment almost vindictive . [Hadria]211-hadria and [the boys]3870-the boys enjoyed nothing better than to watch [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley giving forth [her]141-miss temperley opinions , while [Algitha]81-algitha 's figure gradually stiffened and [her]81-algitha neck drew out , as [Fred]83-fred said , in truly telescopic fashion , like that of [Alice in Wonderland]145-alice in wonderland . [The boys]3870-the boys constructed a figure of cushions , stuffed into one of [Algitha]81-algitha 's old gowns , the neck being a padded broom - handle , made to work up and down at pleasure ; and with this counterfeit presentment of [[their]3870-the boys sister]542-their sister , [they]3870-the boys used to act the scene amidst shouts of applause , [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley entering , on one occasion , when the improvised cocoa - nut head had reached its culminating point of high disdain , somewhere about the level of the curtain - poles . On New - Year's - eve , [Dunaghee]1-dunaghee was full of [guests]4588-guests . There was to be [a children]4589-a children 's party , to which however [most of [the grown - up neighbours]4591-the grown - up neighbours]4590-most of the grown - up neighbours were also invited . “[1352-the devil] What a charming sight ! ” cried [Henriette]142-henriette , standing with [her]142-henriette neat foot on the fender in [the hall]4592-the hall , where [the children]667-the children were playing [blind man]4594-blind man 's buff . [Mrs. Fullerton]97-mrs. fullerton sat watching [them]667-the children with a dreamy smile . The scene recalled many an old memory . [Mr. Fullerton]89-mr. fullerton was playing with [the children]667-the children . [Everyone]3726-everyone remarked how well [the two girls]4597-the two girls looked in [their]4597-the two girls new evening gowns . [They]4597-the two girls had made [them]667-the children [themselves]4597-the two girls , in consequence of a wager with [Fred]83-fred , who had challenged [them]4597-the two girls to combine pink and green satisfactorily . “[1352-the devil] The gowns are perfect ! ” [Temperley]141-miss temperley ventured to remark . “[1352-the devil] So much distinction ! ” “[0-i] All [my]0-i doing , ” cried [Fred]83-fred . “[0-i] [I]0-i chose the colours . ” “[0-i] Distinction comes from within , ” said [Temperley]141-miss temperley . “[0-i] [I]0-i should like to see what sort of gown in pink and green [Mrs.]1356-mrs. — . ” [He]89-mr. fullerton stopped short abruptly . [Fred]83-fred gave a chuckle . Indiscreet eyes wandered towards [Mrs. Gordon]91-mrs. gordon 's brocade and silver . Later in the evening , [that lady]531-that lady played dance music in a florid manner , resembling [her]531-that lady taste in dress . [The younger children]4599-the younger children had gone [home]3770-home , and [the hall]4592-the hall was filled with [spinning couples]4602-spinning couples . “[1356-mrs.] [I]0-i hope [we]1357-we are to have some national dances , ” said [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley . “[0-i] [[My]0-i brother]1358-my brother and [I]0-i are both looking forward to seeing a true reel danced by [natives of [the country]401-the country]1359-natives of the country . ” “[0-i] Oh , certainly ! ” said [Mr. Fullerton]89-mr. fullerton . “[0-i] [[My]0-i daughters]1361-my daughters are rather celebrated for [their]1361-my daughters reels , especially [Hadria]211-hadria . ” [Mr. Fullerton]89-mr. fullerton executed a step or two with great agility . “[3739-the girl] [The girl]3739-the girl gets quite out of [herself]3739-the girl when [she]3739-the girl is dancing , ” said [Mrs. Fullerton]97-mrs. fullerton . “[3739-the girl] [She]3739-the girl wo n't be scolded about it , for [she]3739-the girl says [she]3739-the girl takes after [[her]3739-the girl father]609-her father ! ” “[3739-the girl] That 's the time to get round [her]3739-the girl , ” observed [Fred]83-fred . “[3739-the girl] If [we]1364-we want to set [her]3739-the girl up to some real fun , [we]1364-we always play a reel and wait till [she]3739-the girl 's well into the spirit of the thing , and then , [I]0-i 'll wager , [she]3739-the girl would stick at nothing . ” “[3739-the girl] It 's a fact , ” added [Ernest]86-ernest . “[3739-the girl] It really seems to half mesmerise [her]3739-the girl . ” “[3739-the girl] How very curious ! ” cried [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley . [She]141-miss temperley and [[her]141-miss temperley brother]309-her brother found [themselves]1364-we watching the dancing a little apart from [the others]303-the others . “[0-i] [I]0-i would try again to - night , [Hubert]118-hubert , ” [she]0-i said in a low voice . [He]118-hubert was silent for a moment , twirling the tassel of the curtain . “[118-hubert] There is nothing to be really alarmed at in [her]3739-the girl ideas , regretable as they are . [She]3739-the girl is young . That sort of thing will soon wear off after [she]3739-the girl is married . ” [Temperley]141-miss temperley flung away the tassel . “[3739-the girl] [She]3739-the girl does n't know what [she]3739-the girl is talking about . These high - flown lectures and discussions have filled all [their]1365-they heads with nonsense . It will have to be rooted out when [they]1365-they come to face [the world]334-the world . No use to oppose [her]3739-the girl now . Nothing but experience will teach [her]3739-the girl . [She]3739-the girl must just be humoured for the present . [They]1365-they have all run a little wild in [their]1365-they notions . Time will cure that . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i am sure of it , ” said [Hubert]118-hubert tolerantly . “[0-i] [They]1365-they do n't know the real import of what [they]1365-they say . ” [He]118-hubert hugged this sentence with satisfaction . “[1365-they] [They]1365-they are like [the young Russians one]1367-the young russians one reads about in [Turgenieff]146-turgenieff 's novels , ” said [Henriette—“all]147-henriette—“all[1367-the young russians one] ideas , no commonsense . ” “[1367-the young russians one] And [you]0-i really believe — ? ” [Henriette]142-henriette 's hand was laid comfortingly on [[her]142-henriette brother]309-her brother 's arm . “[0-i] [Dear Hubert]148-hubert , [I]0-i know something of [my]0-i sex . After a year of married life , [a woman]3753-a woman has too many cares and responsibilities to trouble about ideas of this kind , or of any other . ” “[3739-the girl] [She]3739-the girl strikes [me]0-i as being somewhat persistent by nature , ” said [Hubert]148-hubert , choosing a gentler word than obstinate to describe the quality in [the lady]3679-the lady of [his]148-hubert affections . “[3739-the girl] Let [her]3739-the girl be as persistent as [she]3739-the girl may , it is not possible for [any woman]1369-any woman to resist the laws and beliefs of Society . What can [she]3739-the girl do against all [the world]334-the world ? [She]3739-the girl ca n't escape from the conditions of [her]3739-the girl epoch . Oh ! [she]3739-the girl may talk boldly now , for [she]3739-the girl does not understand ; [she]3739-the girl is [a mere infant]1371-a mere infant as regards knowledge of [the world]334-the world , but once [a wife]1373-a wife — ” [Henriette]142-henriette smiled and shook [her]142-henriette head , by way of finish to [her]142-henriette sentence . [Hubert]148-hubert mused silently for some minutes . “[1373-a wife] [I]0-i could not endure that there should be any disturbance — any eccentricity — in [our]1374-our life — ” “[0-i] [[My]0-i dear boy]1375-my dear boy , if [you]1375-my dear boy do n't trust to the teaching of experience to cure [Hadria]211-hadria of these fantastic notions , rely upon the resistless persuasions of [our]1374-our social facts and laws . Nothing can stand against them — certainly not the fretful heresies of [an inexperienced girl]1376-an inexperienced girl , who , remember , is really good and kind at heart . ” “[3739-the girl] Ah ! yes , ” cried [Hubert]148-hubert ; “[3739-the girl] a fine nature , full of good instincts , and womanly to [her]3739-the girl finger - tips . ” “[3739-the girl] Oh ! if [she]3739-the girl were not that , [I]0-i would never encourage [you]1375-my dear boy to think of [her]3739-the girl , ” cried [Henriette]142-henriette with a shudder . “[0-i] It is on this essential goodness of heart that [I]0-i rely . [She]3739-the girl would never be able , try as [she]3739-the girl might , to act in a manner that would really distress those who were dear to [her]3739-the girl . [You]1375-my dear boy may count upon that securely . ” “[1375-my dear boy] Yes ; [I]0-i am sure of it , ” said [Hubert]148-hubert , “[0-i] but unluckily ” ( [he]148-hubert shook [his]148-hubert head and sighed ) “[0-i] [I]0-i am not among those who are dear to [her]3739-the girl . ” [He]148-hubert rose abruptly , and [Henriette]142-henriette followed [him]148-hubert . “[0-i] Try to win [her]3739-the girl to - night , ” [she]0-i murmured , “[0-i] and be sure to express no opposition to [her]3739-the girl ideas , however wild they may be . Ignore [them]1377-them , humour [her]3739-the girl , plead [your]1375-my dear boy cause once more on this auspicious day — the last of the old year . Something tells [me]0-i that the new year will begin joyously for [you]1375-my dear boy . Go now , and good luck to [you]1375-my dear boy . ” “[1375-my dear boy] Ah ! here [you]1375-my dear boy are , ” cried [Mr. Fullerton]89-mr. fullerton , “[1378-we] [we]1378-we were wondering what had become of [you]1375-my dear boy . [You]1375-my dear boy said [you]1375-my dear boy wished to see a reel . [Mrs. McPherson]149-mrs. mcpherson is so good as to play for [us]1378-we . ” [The kindly old Scottish dame]4607-the kindly old scottish dame had come , with [two nieces]4608-two nieces , from a distance of ten miles . A thrill ran through [the company]4609-the company when the strange old tune began . [Everyone]3726-everyone rushed for [a partner]4611-a partner , and two long rows of figures stood facing [one another , eager to start]4612-one another , eager to start . [Temperley]141-miss temperley asked [Hadria]211-hadria to dance with [him]89-mr. fullerton . [Algitha]81-algitha had [Harold Wilkins]94-harold wilkins for [a partner]4611-a partner . [The two long rows]4614-the two long rows were soon stepping and twirling with zest and agility . A new and wilder spirit began to possess [the whole party]1013-the whole party . [The northern blood]4616-the northern blood took fire and transfigured [the dancers]301-the dancers . [The Temperleys]150-the temperleys seemed to be fashioned of different clay ; [they]150-the temperleys were able to keep [their]150-the temperleys heads . [Several elderly people]4618-several elderly people had joined in the dance , performing [their]4618-several elderly people steps with a conscientious dexterity that put some of [[their]4618-several elderly people juniors]4619-their juniors to shame . [Mr. Fullerton]89-mr. fullerton stood by , looking on and applauding . “[149-mrs. mcpherson] How [[your]1379-your father]705-your father seems to enjoy the sight ! ” said [Temperley]141-miss temperley , as [he]705-your father met [[his]705-your father partner]4620-his partner for a moment . “[705-your father] [He]705-your father likes nothing so well , and [[his]705-your father daughters]1381-his daughters take after [him]705-your father . ” [Hadria]211-hadria 's reels were celebrated , not without reason . [Some mad spirit]4621-some mad spirit seemed to possess [her]211-hadria . It would appear almost as if [she]211-hadria had passed into a different phase of character . [She]211-hadria lost caution and care and the sense of external events . When the dance was ended , [Hubert]148-hubert led [her]211-hadria from [the hall]4592-the hall . [She]211-hadria went as if in a dream . [She]211-hadria would not allow [herself]211-hadria to be taken beyond the sound of the grotesque old dance music that was still going on , but otherwise [she]211-hadria was unresisting . [He]148-hubert sat down beside [her]211-hadria in a corner of [the dining - room]1265-the dining - room . Now and then [he]148-hubert glanced at [[his]148-hubert companion]4118-his companion , and seemed about to speak . “[1382-you] [You]1382-you seem fond of [your]1382-you national music , ” [he]148-hubert at last remarked . “[1382-you] It fills [me]0-i with bewildering memories , ” [she]211-hadria said in a dreamy tone . “[1382-you] It seems to recall — it eludes description — some wild , primitive experiences — [mountains]1383-mountains , mists — [I]0-i ca n't express what northern mysteries . It seems almost as if [I]0-i had lived before , among [some ancient Celtic people]1384-some ancient celtic people , and now , when [I]0-i hear [their]1384-some ancient celtic people music — or sometimes when [I]0-i hear the sound of wind among the pines — whiffs and gusts of something intensely familiar return to [me]0-i , and [I]0-i can not grasp it . It is very bewildering . ” “[1384-some ancient celtic people] The only thing that happens to [me]0-i of the kind is that curious sense of having done a thing before . Strange to say , [I]0-i feel it now . This moment is not new to [me]0-i . ” [Hadria]211-hadria gave a startled glance at [[her]211-hadria companion]3995-her companion , and shuddered . “[0-i] [I]0-i suppose it is all pre - ordained , ” [she]211-hadria said . [He]148-hubert was puzzled , but more hopeful than usual . [Hadria]211-hadria might almost have accepted [him]148-hubert in sheer absence of mind . [He]148-hubert put the thought in different terms . [He]148-hubert began to speak more boldly . [He]148-hubert gave [his]148-hubert view of life and happiness , [his]148-hubert philosophy and religion . [Hadria]211-hadria lazily agreed . [She]211-hadria lay under a singular spell . The bizarre old music smote still upon the ear . [She]211-hadria felt as if [she]211-hadria were in the thrall of some dream whose events followed one another , as the scenes of a moving panorama unfold themselves before [the spectators]3788-the spectators . [Temperley]141-miss temperley began to plead [his]148-hubert cause . [Hadria]211-hadria , with a startled look in [her]211-hadria eyes , tried to check [him]148-hubert . But [her]211-hadria will refused to issue a vigorous command . Even had [he]148-hubert been hateful to [her]211-hadria , which [he]148-hubert certainly was not , [she]211-hadria felt that [she]211-hadria would have been unable to wake out of the nightmare , and resume the conduct of affairs . The sense of the importance of personal events had entirely disappeared . What did it all matter ? “[0-i] Over [us]1385-us stars and under [us]1385-us graves . ” [The graves]4627-the graves would put it all right some day . As for attempting to direct [one]329-one 's fate , and struggle out of [the highways of [the world]334-the world]4629-the highways of the world — midsummer madness ! It was not only [the Mrs. Gordons]92-the gordons , but the [Valeria Du Prel]109-valeria who told [one]329-one so . [Everybody]151-everybody said ( but in discreeter terms ) , “[0-i] Disguise from [yourself]1386-you the solitude by setting up little screens of affections , and little pompous affairs about which [you]1386-you must go busily , and with all the solemnity that [you]1386-you can muster . ” [The savage]4632-the savage builds [[his]4632-the savage mud hut]4633-his mud hut to shelter [him]4632-the savage from the wind and the rain and the terror of the beyond . Outside is [the wilderness ready to engulf [him]4632-the savage]4634-the wilderness ready to engulf him . Rather than be left alone at the mercy of elemental things , with [no little hut]4635-no little hut , warm and dark and stuffy , to shelter [one]329-one , [a woman]3753-a woman will sacrifice everything — liberty , ambition , health , power , [her]3753-a woman very dignity . There was a letter in [Hadria]211-hadria 's pocket at this moment , eloquently protesting in favour of [the mud hut]4638-the mud hut . [Hadria]211-hadria must have been appearing to listen favourably to [Temperley]141-miss temperley 's pleading , for [he]4632-the savage said eagerly , “[0-i] Then [I]0-i have not spoken this time quite in vain . [I]0-i may hope that perhaps some day — ” “[0-i] Some day , ” repeated [Hadria]211-hadria , passing [her]211-hadria hand across [her]211-hadria eyes . “[0-i] It does n't really matter . [I]0-i mean [we]1387-we make too much fuss about these trifles ; do n't [you]0-i think so ? ” [She]211-hadria spoke dreamily . The music was jigging on with strange merriment . “[0-i] To [me]0-i it matters very much indeed . [I]0-i do n't consider it a trifle , ” said [Temperley]141-miss temperley , in some bewilderment . “[0-i] Oh , not to [ourselves]1387-we . But of what importance are [we]1387-we ? ” “[0-i] None at all , in a certain sense , ” [Temperley]141-miss temperley admitted ; “[0-i] but in another sense [we]1387-we are all important . [I]0-i can not help being intensely personal at this moment . [I]0-i ca n't help grasping at the hope of happiness . [Hadria]211-hadria , it lies in [your]211-hadria hand . Wo n't [you]211-hadria be generous ? ” [She]211-hadria gave a distressed gesture , and seemed to make some vain effort , as when [the victim of a nightmare]4639-the victim of a nightmare struggles to overcome the paralysis that holds [him]4639-the victim of a nightmare . “[211-hadria] Then [I]0-i may hope a little , [Hadria]211-hadria — [I]0-i must hope . ” Still the trance seemed to hold [her]211-hadria enthralled . The music was diabolically merry . [She]211-hadria could fancy evil spirits tripping to it in swarms around [her]211-hadria . [They]4640-they seemed to point at [her]211-hadria , and wave [their]4640-they arms around [her]211-hadria , and from [them]4640-they came an influence , magnetic in its quality , that forbade [her]211-hadria to resist . All had been pre - arranged . Nothing could avert it . [She]211-hadria seemed to be waiting rather than acting . Against [her]211-hadria inner judgment , [she]211-hadria had allowed those accursed practices to go on . Against [her]211-hadria instinct , [she]211-hadria had permitted [Henriette]142-henriette to become intimate at [Dunaghee]1-dunaghee ; indeed it would have been hard to avoid it , for [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley was not easy to discourage . Why had [she]211-hadria assured [Hadria]211-hadria so pointedly that [Hubert]148-hubert would not misinterpret [her]211-hadria consent to renew the practices ? Was it not a sort of treachery ? Had not [Henriette]142-henriette , with [her]142-henriette larger knowledge of [the world]334-the world , been perfectly well aware that whatever might be said , the renewal of the meetings would be regarded as encouragement ? Did [she]142-henriette not know that [Hadria]211-hadria [herself]211-hadria would feel implicated by the concession ? [Temperley]141-miss temperley 's long silence had been misleading . The danger had crept up insidiously . And had [she]211-hadria not been treacherous to [herself]211-hadria ? [She]211-hadria had longed for companionship , for music , for something to break the strain of [her]211-hadria wild , lonely life . Knowing , or rather half - divining the risk , [she]211-hadria had allowed [herself]211-hadria to accept the chance of relief when it came . Lack of experience had played a large part in the making of to - night 's dilemma . [Hadria]211-hadria 's own strange mood was another ally to [[her]211-hadria lover]4642-her lover , and for that , [old Mrs. McPherson]149-mrs. mcpherson and [her]149-mrs. mcpherson reels were chiefly responsible . Of such flimsy trifles is the human fate often woven . “[0-i] Tell [me]0-i , did [you]0-i ask [[your]0-i sister]1388-your sister to — ? ” “[0-i] No , no , ” [Hubert]148-hubert interposed . “[0-i] [[My]0-i sister]4161-my sister knows of [my]0-i hopes , and is anxious that [I]0-i should succeed . ” “[4161-my sister] [I]0-i thought that [she]4161-my sister was helping [you]0-i . ” “[4161-my sister] [She]4161-my sister would take any legitimate means to help [me]0-i , ” said [Hubert]148-hubert . “[4161-my sister] [You]0-i can not resent that . Ah , [Hadria]211-hadria , why will [you]211-hadria not listen to [me]0-i ? ” [He]148-hubert bent forward , covering [his]148-hubert face with [his]148-hubert hands in deep dejection . [His]148-hubert hope had begun to wane . “[211-hadria] [You]0-i know what [I]0-i think , ” said [Hadria]211-hadria . “[0-i] [You]0-i know how [I]0-i should act if [I]0-i married . Surely that ought to cure [you]0-i of all—. ” [He]148-hubert seized [her]211-hadria hand . “[0-i] No , no , nothing that [you]211-hadria may think could cure [me]0-i of the hope of making [you]211-hadria [[my]0-i wife]1390-my wife . [I]0-i care for what [you]0-i are , not for what [you]0-i think . [You]0-i know how little [I]0-i cling to the popular version of the domestic story . [I]0-i have told [you]211-hadria over and over again that it offends [me]0-i in a thousand ways . [I]0-i hate the bourgeois element in it . What have [we]1391-we really to disagree about ? ” [He]148-hubert managed to be very convincing . [He]148-hubert shewed that for [a woman]3753-a woman , life in [[[her]3753-a woman father]609-her father 's house]4645-her father 's house is far less free than in [[her]3753-a woman own home]4646-her own home ; that existence could be moulded to any shape [she]3753-a woman pleased . If [Hadria]211-hadria hesitated only on this account [her]211-hadria last reason was gone . It was not fair to [him]148-hubert . [He]148-hubert had been patient . [He]148-hubert had kept silence for many months . But [he]148-hubert could endure the suspense no longer . [He]148-hubert took [her]211-hadria hand . Then suddenly [she]211-hadria rose . “[0-i] No , no . [I]0-i ca n't , [I]0-i ca n't , ” [she]211-hadria cried desperately . “[0-i] [I]0-i will not listen to denial , ” [he]148-hubert said following [her]211-hadria . “[0-i] [I]0-i can not stand a second disappointment . [You]0-i have allowed [me]0-i to hope . ” “[0-i] How ? When ? Never ! ” [she]211-hadria exclaimed . “[211-hadria] Ah , yes , [Hadria]211-hadria . [I]0-i am older than [you]211-hadria and [I]0-i have more experience . Do [you]211-hadria think [a man]3704-a man will cease to hope while [he]3704-a man continues to see [the woman [he]3704-a man loves]1393-the woman he loves ? ” [Hadria]211-hadria turned very pale . “[211-hadria] [You]211-hadria seemed to have forgotten — [[your]211-hadria sister]1388-your sister assured [me]0-i — Ah , it was treacherous , it was cruel . [She]1388-your sister took advantage of [my]0-i ignorance , [my]0-i craving for companionship . ” “[1388-your sister] No , it is [you]211-hadria who are cruel , [Hadria]211-hadria , to make such accusations . [I]0-i do not claim the slightest consideration because [you]211-hadria permitted those practices . But [you]211-hadria can not suppose that [my]0-i feeling has not been confirmed and strengthened since [I]0-i have seen [you]211-hadria again . Why should [you]211-hadria turn from [me]0-i ? Why may [I]0-i not hope to win [you]211-hadria ? If [you]211-hadria have no repugnance to [me]0-i , why should not [I]0-i have a chance ? [Hadria]211-hadria , [Hadria]211-hadria , answer [me]0-i , for heaven 's sake . Oh , if [I]0-i could only understand what is in [your]211-hadria mind ! ” [She]211-hadria would have found it a hard task to enlighten [him]4647-him . [He]4647-him had succeeded , to some extent , in lulling [her]211-hadria fears , not in banishing them , for a sinister dread still muttered its warning beneath the surface thoughts . The strength of [Temperley]141-miss temperley 's emotion had stirred [her]211-hadria . The magic of personal influence had begun to tell upon [her]211-hadria . It was so hard not to believe when [some one]3818-some one insisted with such certainty , with such obvious sincerity , that everything would be right . [He]4647-him seemed so confident that [she]211-hadria could make [him]4647-him happy , strange as it appeared . Perhaps after all — ? And what a release from the present difficulties . But could one trust ? A confused mass of feeling struggled together . A temptation to give the answer that would cause pleasure was very strong , and beneath all lurked a trembling hope that perhaps this was the way of escape . In apparent contradiction to this , or to any other hope , lay a sense of fatality , a sad indifference , interrupted at moments by flashes of very desperate caring , when suddenly the love of life , the desire for happiness and experience , for the exercise of [her]211-hadria power , for its use in the service of [[her]211-hadria generation]4649-her generation , became intense , and then faded away again , as obstacles presented [their]4650-their formidable array before the mind . In the midst of the confusion the thought of [the Professor]4071-the professor hovered vaguely , with a dim distressing sense of something wrong , of something within [her]211-hadria lost and wretched and forlorn . [Mrs. Fullerton]97-mrs. fullerton passed through [the room]379-the room on the arm of [Mr. Gordon]93-mr. gordon . How delighted [[her]97-mrs. fullerton mother]520-her mother would be if [she]520-her mother were to give up this desperate attempt to hold out against [her]520-her mother appointed fate . What if [[her]97-mrs. fullerton mother]520-her mother and [Mrs. Gordon]91-mrs. gordon and [all the world]4655-all the world were perfectly right and far - seeing and wise ? Did it not seem more likely , on the face of it , that [they]4650-their should be right , considering the enormous majority of those who would agree with [them]4650-their , than that [she]211-hadria , [Hadria]211-hadria , [a solitary girl , unsupported by knowledge of life]4656-a solitary girl , unsupported by knowledge of life or by [fellow - believers]4657-fellow - believers , should have chanced upon the truth ? Had only [Valeria]109-valeria been on [her]211-hadria side , [she]211-hadria would have felt secure , but [Valeria]109-valeria was dead against [her]211-hadria . “[0-i] [We]1395-we are not really at variance , believe [me]0-i , ” [Temperley]141-miss temperley pleaded . “[0-i] [You]1396-he state things rather more strongly than [I]0-i do — [a man]3704-a man used to knocking about [the world]334-the world — but [I]0-i do n't believe there is any radical difference between [us]1395-we . ” [He]1396-he worked [himself]1396-he up into the belief that there never were [two human beings so essentially at one]4658-two human beings so essentially at one , on all points , as [he]1396-he and [Hadria]211-hadria . “[0-i] Do [you]0-i remember the debate that evening in [the garret]293-the garret ? [Temperley]141-miss temperley remembered . “[0-i] Well , [I]0-i do n't hold those sentiments merely for amusement and recreation . [I]0-i mean them . [She]81-algitha had noticed [her]313-her sister absence during the last reel , and observed that [Temperley]141-miss temperley also was not to be seen . [She]81-algitha felt anxious . [She]81-algitha knew [Hadria]211-hadria 's emotional susceptibility . [She]81-algitha knew [[Temperley]141-miss temperley 's convincing faculty]4665-temperley 's convincing faculty , and also [Hadria]211-hadria 's uneasy feeling that [she]211-hadria had done wrong in allowing the practices to be resumed . [Henriette]142-henriette had not failed to notice the signs of the times , and [she]142-henriette annoyed [Algitha]81-algitha beyond endurance by [her]142-henriette obviously sisterly manner of addressing [the family]360-the family . [Fred]83-fred shared [[his]4668-his sister]351-his sister 's dislike to [Henriette]142-henriette . “[0-i] Tact ! ” [he]4668-his cried with a snort , “[0-i] why a [Temperley]141-miss temperley rushes in where a bull in [a china - shop]1410-a china - shop would fear to tread ! ” [Algitha]81-algitha saw that [Hubert]148-hubert was again by [Hadria]211-hadria 's side before the evening was out . [Tithonius]152-tithonius , [TENNYSON]153-tennyson . [A COUNTRYMAN with stooping gait]4678-a countryman with stooping gait touched [his]4678-a countryman with stooping gait cap and bid good - day to [a young woman who walked rapidly along [the crisp high road]4680-the crisp high road , smiling a response as [she]4679-a young woman who walked rapidly along the crisp high road , smiling a response as she passed passed]4679-a young woman who walked rapidly along the crisp high road , smiling a response as she passed . [The old man]4209-the old man slowly turned to watch the wayfarer , whose quick step and the look in [her]4679-a young woman who walked rapidly along the crisp high road , smiling a response as she passed eyes of being fixed on [objects beyond [[their]4679-a young woman who walked rapidly along the crisp high road , smiling a response as she passed owner]767-their owner 's immediate ken]4685-objects beyond their owner 's immediate ken , might have suggested to [the observant , inward perturbation]4687-the observant , inward perturbation . [The lissom , swiftly moving figure]4688-the lissom , swiftly moving figure was almost out of sight before [the old man]4209-the old man slowly wheeled round and continued on [his]4209-the old man way towards [the hamlet of [Craddock Dene]22-craddock dene]4690-the hamlet of craddock dene , that lay in [the valley about a mile further on]4691-the valley about a mile further on . [A row of [broad - tiled cottages]4696-broad - tiled cottages]4695-a row of broad - tiled cottages came in sight , and on [the hill]3975-the hill - side [the vicarage]4698-the vicarage among trees , and [a grey stone church which had seen many changes since [its]4699-a grey stone church which had seen many changes since its tower first looked out from the hill - top over the southern counties tower first looked out from [the hill - top]4700-the hill - top over [the southern counties]4701-the southern counties]4699-a grey stone church which had seen many changes since its tower first looked out from the hill - top over the southern counties . [The little village]4702-the little village seemed as if [it]4702-the little village had forgotten to change with [the rest of [the country]401-the country]4703-the rest of the country , for at least a hundred years . The spirit of the last century lingered in [[its]4702-the little village quiet cottages]4705-its quiet cottages , in [the little ale - house with half - obliterated sign , in [its]4702-the little village air of absolute repose and leisure]4706-the little ale - house with half - obliterated sign , in its air of absolute repose and leisure . There was no evidence of contest anywhere — except perhaps in a few mouldy advertisements of [a circus]4707-a circus and of a remarkable kind of soap , that were half peeling off a moss - covered wall . There were not even many indications of life in [the place]981-the place . The sunshine seemed to have [[the village]1124-the village street]4710-the village street to [itself]4710-the village street . [A couple of women]4711-a couple of women stood gossiping over the gate of [one of [the cottages]4713-the cottages]4712-one of the cottages . [They]4711-a couple of women paused in [their]4711-a couple of women talk as a quick step sounded on [the road]4037-the road . “[0-i] There be [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley again ! ” [one matron]4715-one matron exclaimed . “[154-mrs. temperley] Why this is the second time this week , as [she]154-mrs. temperley 's come and sat in [the churchyard]1413-the churchyard along o ' the dead . Do n't seem nat'ral to [my]0-i thinking . ” [Mrs. Dodge]155-dodge and [Mrs. Gullick]156-mrs. gullick continued to discuss this gloomy habit with exhaustive minuteness , involving [themselves]4711-a couple of women in side issues regarding the general conduct of life on the part of [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley , that promised solid material for conversation for the next week . It appeared from the observations of [[Mrs. Gullick]156-mrs. gullick , whose husband worked on [[Lord Engleton]157-lord engleton 's model farm]4717-lord engleton 's model farm]4716-mrs. gullick , whose husband worked on lord engleton 's model farm , that about five years ago [Mr. Temperley]118-hubert had rented [the Red House]4718-the red house at [Craddock Dene]22-craddock dene , and had brought [[his]118-hubert new wife]4719-his new wife to live [there]571-there . [The Red House]4718-the red house belonged to [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue , who also owned [the Priory , which had stood empty]4722-the priory , which had stood empty , said [Mrs. Gullick]156-mrs. gullick , since that poor [Mrs. Fortescue]158-mrs. fortescue killed [herself]158-mrs. fortescue in [the old drawing - room]4723-the old drawing - room . [Mr. Temperley]118-hubert went every day to [town]4255-town to attend to [his]118-hubert legal business , and returned by [the evening train]4725-the evening train to [the bosom of [[his]118-hubert family]3868-his family]4726-the bosom of his family . [That family]4728-that family now consisted in [[his]118-hubert wife]573-his wife and [two small boys]4730-two small boys ; [pretty little fellows]4731-pretty little fellows , added [Mrs. Dodge]155-dodge , [the pride of [[their]4730-two small boys parents]361-their parents ' hearts]4732-the pride of their parents ' hearts ; at least , so [she]155-dodge had heard [Mr. Joseph Fleming]159-joseph fleming say , and [he]159-joseph fleming was intimate at [the Red House]4718-the red house . [Mrs. Gullick]156-mrs. gullick did not exactly approve of [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley . [The Red House]4718-the red house was not , it would seem , an everflowing fount of sustaining port wine and spiritually nourishing literature . The moral evolution of [the village]1124-the village had proceeded on those lines . The prevailing feeling was vaguely hostile ; neither [Mrs. Gullick]156-mrs. gullick nor [Mrs. Dodge]155-dodge exactly knew why . [Mrs. Dodge]155-dodge said that [[her]155-dodge husband]553-her husband ( who was [the sexton and gravedigger]4738-the sexton and gravedigger ) had found [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley always ready for a chat . [He]553-her husband spoke well of [her]154-mrs. temperley . But [Dodge]155-dodge was not one of many . [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley was perhaps too sensitively respectful of the feelings of [[her]154-mrs. temperley poorer neighbours]4739-her poorer neighbours to be very popular among [them]4739-her poorer neighbours . At any rate , [her]154-mrs. temperley habits of seclusion did not seem to [village]4740-village philosophy to be justifiable in the eyes of [God]139-god or [man]332-man . [Her]154-mrs. temperley apparent fondness for [the society of the dead]4742-the society of the dead also caused displeasure . Why [she]154-mrs. temperley went to [the churchyard]1413-the churchyard could not be imagined : [one]329-one would think [she]154-mrs. temperley had [a family]4521-a family buried [there]571-there , [she]154-mrs. temperley who was , “[1414-a stranger to the place] as one might say , [a stranger to [the place]981-the place]1414-a stranger to the place , ” and could not be supposed to have any interest in the graves , which held for [her]154-mrs. temperley nor [kith]4747-kith nor kin ! [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley , however , appeared to be able to dispense with this element of attraction in [the “[1414-a stranger to the place] grassy barrows]4748-the “ grassy barrows . ” [She]154-mrs. temperley and a company of [youthful Cochin - China fowls]4749-youthful cochin - china fowls remained for hours among [them]4749-youthful cochin - china fowls , on this cheerful morning , and [no observer]4750-no observer could have determined whether it was the graves or the fowls that riveted [her]154-mrs. temperley attention . [She]154-mrs. temperley had perched [herself]154-mrs. temperley on the stile that led from [the churchyard]1413-the churchyard to [the fields]4328-the fields : [a slender figure in serviceable russet and irresponsible - looking hat , autumn - tinted too]4753-a slender figure in serviceable russet and irresponsible - looking hat , autumn - tinted too , in sympathy with the splendid season . In [her]154-mrs. temperley ungloved left hand , which was at once sensitive and firm , [she]154-mrs. temperley carried a book , keeping a forefinger between the pages to mark a passage . [Her]154-mrs. temperley face bore signs of suffering , and at this moment , a look of baffled and restless longing , as if life had been for [her]154-mrs. temperley a festival whose sounds came from a hopeless distance . Yet there was something in the expression of the mouth , that suggested a consistent standing aloof from [herself]154-mrs. temperley and [her]154-mrs. temperley desires . The lines of the face could never have been drawn by mere diffusive , emotional habits . Thought had left as many traces as feeling in the firm drawing . The quality of the face was of that indefinable kind that gives to all characteristic things their peculiar power over the imagination . The more powerful the quality , the less can it be rendered into terms . It is the one marvellous , remaining , musical fact not to [he]4754-he defined that makes [the Parthenon]4755-the parthenon , or some other masterpiece of art , translate [us]4756-us to a new plane of existence , and inspire , for the time being , [the pessimist with hope]4757-the pessimist with hope and [the sceptic with religion]4758-the sceptic with religion . [The Cochin - Chinas]160-the cochin - chinas pecked about with [a contented mien among the long grass]4759-a contented mien among the long grass , finding odds and ends of nourishment , and here and there eking out [their]4760-their livelihood with a dart at a passing fly . [Their]4760-their long , comic , tufted legs , which seemed to form a sort of monumental pedestal whereon the bird itself was elevated , stalked and scratched about with an air of industrious serenity . There were few mornings in the year which left unstirred the grass which grew long over [the graves]4627-the graves , but this was one of the few . Each blade stood up still and straight , bearing its string of dewdrops . There were one or two village sounds that came subdued through the sunshine . The winds that usually haunted [the high spot]4762-the high spot had fallen asleep , or were lying somewhere in ambush among [the woodlands beyond]4763-the woodlands beyond . The look of strain had faded from the face of [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley , leaving only an expression of sadness . The removal of all necessity for concealing thought allowed [her]154-mrs. temperley story to write itself on [her]154-mrs. temperley face . [The speculative]4764-the speculative would have felt some curiosity as to the cause of a sadness in one seemingly so well treated by destiny . Neither poverty nor the cares of great wealth could have weighed upon [her]154-mrs. temperley spirit ; [she]154-mrs. temperley had beauty , and a quality more attractive than beauty , which must have placed many things at [her]154-mrs. temperley command ; [she]154-mrs. temperley had evident talent — [her]154-mrs. temperley very attitude proclaimed it — and the power over Fortune that talent ought to give . Possibly , [the observer]4765-the observer might reflect , the gift was of that kind which lays [the possessor]4766-the possessor peculiarly open to [her]154-mrs. temperley outrageous slings and arrows . Had [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley shown any morbid signs of self - indulgent emotionalism the problem would have been simple enough but this was not the case . The solitude was presently broken by the approach of [an old man laden with pickaxe and shovel]4767-an old man laden with pickaxe and shovel . [He]4767-an old man laden with pickaxe and shovel remarked upon the fineness of the day , and took up [his]4767-an old man laden with pickaxe and shovel position at a short distance from [the stile]4768-the stile , where the turf had been cleared away in a long - shaped patch . Here , with great deliberation [he]4767-an old man laden with pickaxe and shovel began [his]4767-an old man laden with pickaxe and shovel task . The sound of [his]4767-an old man laden with pickaxe and shovel steady strokes fell on the stillness . Presently , the clock from [the grey tower]4769-the grey tower gave forth [its]4770-its announcement — eleven . One by one , the slow hammer sent the waves of air rolling away , almost visibly , through the sunshine , their sound alternating with the thud of the pickaxe , so as to produce an effect of intentional rhythm . [One]329-one might have fancied that clock and pickaxe iterated in turn , “[154-mrs. temperley] Time , Death ! Time , Death ! Time , Death ! ” till the clock had come to the end of its tale , and then the pickaxe went on alone in the stillness—“Death[1417-lord] ! Death ! Death ! Death ! ” A smile , not easy to be accounted for , flitted across the face of [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley . [The old gravedigger]4772-the old gravedigger paused at last in [his]4772-the old gravedigger toil , leaning on [his]4772-the old gravedigger pickaxe , and bringing a red cotton handkerchief out of [his]4772-the old gravedigger hat to wipe [his]4772-the old gravedigger brow . “[155-dodge] That seems rather hard work , [Dodge]155-dodge , ” remarked [the onlooker]3966-the onlooker , leaning [her]0-i book upright on [her]0-i knee and [her]0-i chin on [her]0-i hand . “[155-dodge] Ay , that it be , [mum]1416-mum ; this clay 's that stiff ! [Lord]1417-lord ! [folks]1418-folks is almost as much trouble to [them]1418-folks as buries as to [them]1418-folks as [bears 'em]1419-bears 'em ; it 's all trouble together , to [my]0-i thinkin ' . ” [She]1416-mum assented with a musing nod . “[1422-a troublin ' of hisself] And when [a man]3704-a man 's not [a troublin ' o ' some other body]1421-a troublin ' o ' some other body , [he]3704-a man 's [a troublin ' of hisself]1422-a troublin ' of hisself , ” added [the philosopher]4774-the philosopher . “[3704-a man] [You]155-dodge are cursed with a clear - sightedness that must make life a burden to [you]155-dodge , ” said [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley . “[155-dodge] Well , [mum]1416-mum , [I]0-i do sort o ' see the bearin 's o ' things better nor most , ” [Dodge]155-dodge modestly admitted . [The lady]3679-the lady knew , and liked to gratify , [the gravedigger]4776-the gravedigger 's love of long - worded discourse . “[0-i] [Some people]1424-some people , ” [she]3679-the lady said , “[0-i] are born contemplative , while [others]432-others never reflect at all , whatever the provocation . ” “[432-others] Yes'm , that 's just it ; [folks]1418-folks goes on as if [they]1418-folks was to live for ever , without no thought o ' dyin ' . There was a long pause , during which the stillness seemed to weigh upon the air , as if the pressure of [Fate]102-fate were hanging there with ruthless immobility . “[1488-one of the neighbours , name o ' gullick , as her husband] [She]1488-one of the neighbours , name o ' gullick , as her husband ai n't got no more to suffer now , ” [Dodge]155-dodge remarked , nodding with an aspect of half apology towards [the grave]4790-the grave . “[1501-they] [They]1501-they sleeps soft as sleeps [here]3762-here . ” “[1501-they] Good heavens , [I]0-i hope so ! ” [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley exclaimed . [The grave]4790-the grave had made considerable progress before [she]0-i descended from the stile and prepared to take [her]0-i homeward way . On leaving , [she]0-i made [Dodge]155-dodge come with [her]0-i to the gate , and point out [the red - roofed cottage covered with monthly roses and flaming creeper]4792-the red - roofed cottage covered with monthly roses and flaming creeper , where [the schoolmistress]4793-the schoolmistress had passed so many years , and where [she]0-i now lay with [her]0-i work and [her]0-i days all over , in [the tiny upper room]4794-the tiny upper room , at whose latticed window the sun used to wake [her]0-i on summer mornings , or the winter rain pattered dreary prophecies of the tears that [she]0-i would one day shed . “[1501-they] IF [you]0-i please , [ma'am]1503-ma'am , [the cook]1504-the cook says as the meat has n't come for lunch , and what is [she]1504-the cook to do ? ” “[1504-the cook] Without , ” replied [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley automatically . [The maid]766-the maid waited for more discreet directions . [She]766-the maid had given a month 's notice that very morning , because [she]766-the maid found [Craddock Dene]164-craddock dene too dull . “[1504-the cook] Thank goodness , that barbarian is going ! ” [Hubert]118-hubert had exclaimed . “[1505-we] [We]1505-we shall but exchange [a Goth]1506-a goth for [a Vandal]1507-a vandal , ” [[his]118-hubert wife]573-his wife replied . [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley gazed intently at [[her]154-mrs. temperley maid]4797-her maid , the light of intelligence gradually dawning in [her]154-mrs. temperley countenance . “[1507-a vandal] Is there anything else in [the house]296-the house , [Sapph]165-sapph — [Sophia]166-sophia ? ” “[166-sophia] No , [ma'am]1503-ma'am , ” replied [Sophia]166-sophia . “[1503-ma'am] Oh , tell [the cook]1504-the cook to make it into a fricassee , and be sure it is well flavoured . ” [The maid]766-the maid hesitated , but seeing from the wandering expression of [[her]766-the maid employer]4799-her employer 's eye that [her]766-the maid intellect was again clouded over , [she]766-the maid retired to give the message to [the cook]1504-the cook — with comments . [The library at [the Red House]4718-the red house]4801-the library at the red house was [the only room that had been radically altered since the days of [the former tenants , whose taste had leant towards the florid rather than the classic]4804-the former tenants , whose taste had leant towards the florid rather than the classic]4803-the only room that had been radically altered since the days of the former tenants , whose taste had leant towards the florid rather than the classic . The general effect had been toned down , but it was impossible to disguise the leading motive ; or what [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley passionately described as its brutal vulgarity . [The library]4805-the library alone had been subjected to peine forte et dure . [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley said that [it]4805-the library had been purified by suffering . By dint of tearing down and dragging out offending objects ( “[1503-ma'am] such a pity ! ” cried [the neighbours]1469-the neighbours ) its prosperous and complacent absurdity had been humbled . [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley retired to [this refuge]4807-this refuge after [her]154-mrs. temperley encounter with [Sophia]166-sophia . [That perennially aggrieved young person]4808-that perennially aggrieved young person entered almost immediately afterwards and announced [a visitor]4809-a visitor , with an air that implied—“She'll[1503-ma'am] stay to lunch ; see if [she]1511-she do n't , and what 'll [you]1512-you do then ? [Yah]1513-yah ! ” The pronunciation of [the visitor]4013-the visitor 's name was such , that , for the moment , [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley did not recognize it as that of [Miss Valeria Du Prel]109-valeria . [She]154-mrs. temperley jumped up joyfully . “[1513-yah] Ah , [Valeria]109-valeria , this is delightful ! ” The visit was explained after a characteristic fashion . [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria realized that over two years had passed since [she]109-valeria had seen [Hadria]211-hadria , and moreover [she]109-valeria had been seized with an overwhelming longing for a sight of [country fields]4811-country fields and a whiff of country air , so [she]109-valeria had put a few things together in a handbag , which [she]109-valeria had left at [Craddock station]23-craddock by accident , and come down . Was there anyone who could go and fetch [her]109-valeria handbag ? It was such a nuisance ; [she]109-valeria laid it down for a moment to get at [her]109-valeria ticket — [she]109-valeria never could find [her]109-valeria pocket , [dressmakers]4812-dressmakers always hid them in such an absurd way ; could [Hadria]211-hadria recommend [any dressmaker who did not hide pockets]4813-any dressmaker who did not hide pockets ? Was n't it tiresome ? [She]109-valeria had no time - table , and so [she]109-valeria had gone to [the station]3893-the station that morning and waited till [a Craddock train]4815-a craddock train started , and by this arrangement it had come to pass that [she]109-valeria had spent an hour and a half on [the platform]3895-the platform : [she]109-valeria did not think [she]109-valeria ever had such an unpleasant time ; why did n't [they]4812-dressmakers have [trains]4817-trains oftener ? [They]4812-dressmakers did to [Putney]26-putney . [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley sat down and laughed . Whereupon [the other]3994-the other 's face lightened and [she]154-mrs. temperley joined in the laugh at [her]154-mrs. temperley own expense , settling into the easy chair that [[her]154-mrs. temperley hostess]4819-her hostess had prepared for [her]154-mrs. temperley , with a gesture of helplessness and comfort . “[109-valeria] Well , in spite of that time at [the station]3893-the station , [I]0-i 'm glad [I]0-i came . It seems so long since [I]0-i have seen [you]1515-you , dear [Hadria]211-hadria , and the last time [you]1515-you know [you]1515-you were very unhappy , almost mad — ” “[1515-you] Yes , yes ; never mind about that , ” interposed [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley hastily , setting [her]154-mrs. temperley teeth together . “[1515-you] [You]1515-you take things too hard , too hard , ” said [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria . “[1515-you] [I]0-i used to think [I]0-i was bad in that way , but [I]0-i am phlegmatic compared with [you]1515-you . [One]329-one would suppose that — ” “[329-one] [Valeria]109-valeria , do n't , do n't , do n't , ” cried [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley . “[329-one] [I]0-i ca n't stand it . ” [Her]154-mrs. temperley teeth were still set tight and hard , [her]154-mrs. temperley hands were clenched . “[0-i] Very well , very well . Tell [me]0-i what [you]1515-you have been making of [this ridiculous old world]1517-this ridiculous old world , where everything goes wrong and [everybody]3781-everybody is stupid or wicked , or both . ” [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley 's face relaxed a little , though the signs of some strong emotion were still visible . “[1515-you] Well , to answer [the general]1519-the general by the particular , [I]0-i have spent the morning , accompanied by [a nice young brood of Cochin - China fowls]1520-a nice young brood of cochin - china fowls , in [Craddock churchyard]1521-craddock churchyard . ” “[1520-a nice young brood of cochin - china fowls] Oh , [I]0-i hate [a churchyard]1522-a churchyard , ” exclaimed [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria , with a shudder . “[0-i] It makes [one]329-one think of the hideous mockery of life , and the more one would like to die , the worse seems the brutality of death and [his]329-one hideous accompaniments . It is such a savage denial of all human aspirations and affections and hopes . Ah , it is horrible ! ” The sharply - outlined face grew haggard and white , as [its owner]559-its owner crouched over the fire . “[167-heaven] [Heaven]167-heaven knows ! but it was very serene and very lovely up there this morning . ” “[167-heaven] Ah ! ” exclaimed [Valeria]109-valeria with a burst of strange enthusiasm and sadness , that revealed all the fire and yearning and power that had raised [her]109-valeria above [[her]109-valeria fellows]4821-her fellows in the scale of consciousness , with the penalty of a life of solitude and of sorrow . “[167-heaven] Surely it is not without meaning that the places of the dead are [the serenest spots on [earth]787-earth]1524-the serenest spots on earth , ” said [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley . “[167-heaven] If [I]0-i could keep [myself]0-i in the mood that [the place]981-the place induces , [I]0-i think [I]0-i should not mind anything very much any more . The sunshine seems to rest more tenderly there than elsewhere , and the winds have a reverence for the graves , as if [they]1527-they felt it time that [the dead]1528-the dead were left in peace — [the ‘ happier dead]1529-the ‘ happier dead , ’ as [poor immortal Tithonius]152-tithonius calls [them]1528-the dead , who has not the gift of death . And [the grey old tower]1530-the grey old tower and the weather stains on the stones ; there is a conspiracy of beauty in [the place]981-the place , that holds [one as one is held by music]1532-one as one is held by music . ” “[1532-one as one is held by music] Ah ! [I]0-i know the magic of these things ; it tempts [one]329-one to believe at times that Nature is not all blind and unpitying . But that is a delusion : if there were any pity in Nature , the human spirit would not be dowered with such infinite and terrible longings and such capacities and dreams and prayers and then — then insulted with the mockery of death and annihilation . ” “[1535-you] If there should be no Beyond , ” muttered [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley . “[1535-you] That to [me]0-i is inconceivable . When [we]1534-we die [we]1534-we fall into an eternal sleep . Moreover , [I]0-i can see no creed that does not add the fear of future torments to the certainties of these . ” [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley was seized with a bitter mood . “[1535-you] [You]1535-you should cultivate faith , ” [she]154-mrs. temperley said ; “[1535-you] it acts the part of the heading ‘ Sundries omitted ’ in one 's weekly accounts ; [one]329-one can put down under it everything that ca n't be understood — but [you]1535-you do n't keep weekly accounts , so it 's no use pointing out to [you]1535-you the peace that comes of that device . ” The entrance of [Sophia]166-sophia with firewood turned the current of conversation . “[0-i] Good heavens ! [I]0-i do n't think [we]1534-we have anything for lunch ! ” [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley exclaimed . “[0-i] Are [you]1535-you very hungry ? What is to be done ? It was the faithlessness of [[our]1534-we butcher]1537-our butcher that disturbed the serenity of [my]0-i mood this morning . Perhaps [the poor beast whose carcase [we]1534-we were intending to devour]1538-the poor beast whose carcase we were intending to devour will feel serene instead of [me]0-i : but , alas ! [I]0-i fear [he]1538-the poor beast whose carcase we were intending to devour has been slaughtered quand même . That is one of the unsatisfactory things about life : that all its worst miseries bring good to [no one]383-no one . [One]329-one may deny [oneself]329-one , but not a living thing is necessarily the better for it — generally many are the worse . The wheels of pain go turning day by day , and [the gods]812-the gods stand aloof — [they]812-the gods will not help [us]1534-we , nor will [they]812-the gods stay the ‘ wild world ’ in its course . No , no , ” added [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley with a laugh , “[0-i] [I]0-i am not tired of life , but [I]0-i am tired with it ; it wo n't give [me]0-i what [I]0-i want . That is perhaps because [I]0-i want so much . ” The sound of male footsteps in [the hall]4592-the hall broke up the colloquy . “[0-i] Good heavens ! What fatality can have induced [him]118-hubert to choose to - day of all others for this orgy of hospitality ? ” “[1543-a crowd of people] Does the day matter ? ” enquired [Valeria]109-valeria , astonished at so much emotion . “[1543-a crowd of people] Does the day matter ! Oh irresponsible question of the unwedded ! [He]118-hubert used to be amused by [[his]118-hubert wife]573-his wife 's flippancy before [her]573-his wife marriage , but [he]118-hubert had long since grown to dislike it .
