[Mrs. Walker]162-mrs. walker had heard that [the two Professors]1667-the two professors had arrived at [Craddock Place]29-craddock place yesterday afternoon , and [the Engletons]194-the engletons expected [them]1667-the two professors to make a visit of some weeks . [Hadria]211-hadria 's face brightened . “ And so at last [we]5124-we may hope that [the Priory]1664-the priory will be inhabited , ”[4965-the vicar] said [[the vicar]4965-the vicar 's wife]4966-the vicar 's wife . “ Of course [you]162-mrs. walker know , ”[4966-the vicar 's wife] [she]4966-the vicar 's wife added in the pained voice that [she]4966-the vicar 's wife always reserved for anecdotes of local ill - doing , “ that [Mrs. Fortescue]158-mrs. fortescue committed suicide [there]571-there . ”[4966-the vicar 's wife] [Madame Bertaux]195-madame bertaux , [the English wife of [a French official]1853-a french official]1852-the english wife of a french official , had chanced to call , and [Mrs. Walker]162-mrs. walker gave the details of the story for the benefit of [the new - comer]1028-the new - comer . [Madame Bertaux]195-madame bertaux was [a brisk , clever , good - looking woman , with a profound knowledge of [the world]334-the world and a corresponding contempt for it]1855-a brisk , clever , good - looking woman , with a profound knowledge of the world and a corresponding contempt for it . It appeared that [[the Professor]4071-the professor 's wife , whom [Madame Bertaux]195-madame bertaux had happened to meet in [Paris]35-paris]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris , was [a young , beautiful , and self - willed girl , passionately devoted to [[her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris husband]553-her husband]1859-a young , beautiful , and self - willed girl , passionately devoted to her husband . [She]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris was piqued at [his]553-her husband lack of jealousy , and doubted or pretended to doubt [his]553-her husband love for [her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris . In order to put [him]553-her husband to the test , [she]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris determined to rouse [his]553-her husband jealousy by violent and systematic flirtation . This led to an entanglement , and finally , in a fit of reckless anger , to an elopement with [a Captain Bolton who was staying at [the Priory]1664-the priory at the time]1861-a captain bolton who was staying at the priory at the time . Seized with remorse , [she]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris had returned [home]3770-home to kill [herself]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris . This was the tragedy that had kept [the old house]742-the old house for so many years tenantless . [Hadria]211-hadria 's music was the only sound that had disturbed [its]742-the old house silence , since the day when the dead body of [[its]742-the old house mistress]1682-its mistress was found in [the drawing - room]737-the drawing - room , which [she]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris was supposed to have entered unknown to [anyone]806-anyone , by the window that gave on to [the terrace]1680-the terrace . [Valeria Du Prel]109-valeria was able to throw more light on the strange story . [She]109-valeria had difficulty in speaking without rancour of [the woman who had thrown away the love of [such a man]1870-such a man]1869-the woman who had thrown away the love of such a man . [She]109-valeria admitted that [the girl]3739-the girl was extremely fascinating , and had seemed to [Valeria]109-valeria to have the faults of an impetuous rather than of a bad nature . [She]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris cherished that singular desire of [many strong - willed women]1872-many strong - willed women , to be ruled and mastered by [the man [she]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris loved]1873-the man she loved , and [she]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris had entirely failed to understand [[her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris husband]553-her husband 's attitude towards [her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris . [She]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris resented it as a sign of indifference . [She]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris was like [the Chinese wives , who complain bitterly of [a husband]512-a husband 's neglect when [he]512-a husband omits to beat [them]1875-the chinese wives , who complain bitterly of a husband 's neglect when he omits to beat them]1875-the chinese wives , who complain bitterly of a husband 's neglect when he omits to beat them . [She]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris taunted [the Professor]4071-the professor for failing to assert [his]4071-the professor “ rights . ”[1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris] “ Morally , [I]4071-the professor have no rights , except such as [you]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris choose to give [me]4071-the professor of [your]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris own free will , ”[4071-the professor] [he]4071-the professor replied . “ [I]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris am not [[your]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris gaoler]5127-your gaoler . ”[1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris] “ And even that did not penetrate to [her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris better nature till it was too late , ”[109-valeria] [Valeria]109-valeria continued . “ But after the mischief was done , that phrase seems to have stung [her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris to torment . [Her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris training had blinded [her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris , as [one]329-one is blinded in coming out of darkness into a bright light . [She]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris was used to narrower hearts and smaller brains . [Her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris last letter — a terrible record of the miseries of remorse — [shews]5129-shews that [she]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris recognized at last what sort of [a man [he]4071-the professor was whose heart [she]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris had broken]5130-a man he was whose heart she had broken . But even in [her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris repentance , [she]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris was unable to conquer [her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris egotism . [She]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris could not face the horrors of self - accusation ; [she]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris preferred to kill [herself]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris . ”[109-valeria] “ What a shocking story ! ”[211-hadria] cried [Hadria]211-hadria . “ And all the more so because [the Professor]4071-the professor clings to [her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris memory so faithfully . [He]4071-the professor blames [himself]4071-the professor for everything . [He]4071-the professor ought , [he]4071-the professor says , to have realized better the influence of [her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris training ; [he]4071-the professor ought to have made [her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris understand that [he]4071-the professor could not assert what [she]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris called [his]4071-the professor ‘ rights ’ without insulting [her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris and [himself]4071-the professor . ”[211-hadria] “ Whenever [one]329-one hears anything new about [the Professor]4071-the professor , it is always something that makes [one]329-one admire and love [him]1878-him more than ever ! ”[211-hadria] cried [Hadria]211-hadria . [Her]211-hadria first meeting with [him]1878-him was in [the old [Yew Avenue]36-yew avenue in [the Priory garden]1677-the priory garden]1879-the old yew avenue in the priory garden . [He]1878-him was on [his]1878-him way to call at [the Red House]4718-the red house . [She]211-hadria stood on a patch of grass by a rustic seat commanding the vista of yews , and above [them]1882-them , a wilderness of lilacs and laburnums , in full flower . [It]1883-it looked to [her]211-hadria like [a pathway that led to [some exquisite fairy palace of]1885-some exquisite fairy palace of [one]329-one 's childhood]1884-a pathway that led to some exquisite fairy palace of one 's childhood . Almost with the first word that [the Professor]4071-the professor uttered , [Hadria]211-hadria felt a sense of relief and hope . The very air seemed to grow lighter , the scent of the swaying flowers sweeter . [She]211-hadria always afterwards associated this moment of meeting with the image of that avenue of mourning yews , crowned with the sunlit magnificence of an upper world of blossom . What had [she]211-hadria been thinking of to run so close to despair during these years ? A word , a smile , and the dead weight swerved , swung into balance , and life lifted up its head once more . [She]211-hadria remembered now , not [her]211-hadria limitations , but the good things of [her]211-hadria lot ; the cruelties that Fate had spared [her]211-hadria , the miseries that [the ruthless goddess]1888-the ruthless goddess had apportioned to [others]432-others . But [the Professor]4071-the professor 's presence did not banish , but rather emphasized , the craving to take part in the enriching of that general life which was so poor and sad . [He]4071-the professor strengthened [her]211-hadria disposition to revolt against the further impoverishment of it , through the starving of [her]211-hadria own nature . [He]4071-the professor would not blame [her]211-hadria simply on account of difference from [others]432-others . [She]211-hadria felt sure of that . [He]4071-the professor would not be shocked if [she]211-hadria had not answered to the stimulus of surroundings as faithfully as [most women]4904-most women seemed to answer to [them]4904-most women . [Circumstance]106-circumstance had done its usual utmost to excite [her]211-hadria instinct to beat down the claims of [[her]211-hadria other self]1893-her other self , but for once , circumstance had failed . It was a solitary failure among a creditable multitude of victories . But if instinct had not responded to the imperious summons , [the other self]1894-the other self had been suffering the terrors of a siege , and [the garrison]1895-the garrison had grown starved and weakly . What would be the end of it ? And [the little cynical imp that peeped among [her]211-hadria thoughts]1896-the little cynical imp that peeped among her thoughts , as [a monkey among forest boughs]1897-a monkey among forest boughs , gibbered [his]1896-the little cynical imp that peeped among her thoughts customary “ What matters it ? [One woman]5135-one woman 's destiny is but a small affair . If [I]1896-the little cynical imp that peeped among her thoughts were [you]211-hadria [I]1896-the little cynical imp that peeped among her thoughts would make less fuss about it . ”[1896-the little cynical imp that peeped among her thoughts] [The Professor]4071-the professor would understand that [she]211-hadria did not wish to make a fuss . [He]4071-the professor would not be hard upon [any human being]1899-any human being . [He]4071-the professor knew that existence was not such an easy affair to manage . [She]211-hadria wished that [she]211-hadria could tell [him]4071-the professor everything in [her]211-hadria life — its struggle , its desperate longing and ambition , its hatred , its love : only [he]4071-the professor would understand all the contradictions and all the pain . [She]211-hadria would not mind [his]4071-the professor blame , because [he]4071-the professor would understand , and the blame would be just . [They]1900-they walked together down [the avenue]945-the avenue towards [the beautiful old Tudor house]1902-the beautiful old tudor house , which stood on the further side of [a broad lawn]1903-a broad lawn . [The Professor]4071-the professor looked worn and thin . [He]4071-the professor owned to being very tired of the hurry and struggle of [town]4255-town . [He]4071-the professor was sick of the conflict of jealousies and ambitions . It seemed so little worth while , this din of voices that would so soon be silenced . “ [I]211-hadria starve for the sight of a true and simple face , for the grasp of a brotherly hand . ”[211-hadria] “ [You]4071-the professor ? ”[211-hadria] exclaimed [Hadria]211-hadria . “ There are so few , so very few , where the throng is thick and the battle fierce . It saddens [me]211-hadria to see [good fellows]5136-good fellows trampling [one another]3945-one another down , growing hard and ungenerous . And then the vulgarity , the irreverence : they are almost identical , [I]211-hadria think . [One]329-one grows very sick and sorry at times amidst the cruelty and the baseness that threaten to destroy [one]329-one 's courage and [one]329-one 's hope . [I]211-hadria know that human nature has in it a germ of nobility that will save it , in the long run , but meanwhile things seem sadly out of joint . ”[211-hadria] “ Is that the order of the universe ? ”[211-hadria] asked [Hadria]211-hadria . “ No , [I]4071-the professor think it is rather the disorder of [man]332-man 's nature , ”[4071-the professor] [he]4071-the professor replied . [Hadria]211-hadria asked if [he]4071-the professor would return to tea at [the Red House]4718-the red house . [The Professor]4071-the professor said [he]4071-the professor would like to call and see [Hubert]118-hubert , but proposed a rest on [the terrace]1680-the terrace , as it was still early in the afternoon . “ [I]4071-the professor used to avoid [the place]981-the place , ”[4071-the professor] [he]4071-the professor said , “ but [I]4071-the professor made a mistake . [I]4071-the professor have resolved to face the memories : it is better . ”[4071-the professor] It was the first time that [he]4071-the professor had ever referred , in [Hadria]211-hadria 's presence , to the tragedy of [the Priory]1664-the priory . “ [I]4071-the professor have often wished to speak to [you]211-hadria about [[my]4071-the professor wife]1390-my wife , ”[4071-the professor] [he]4071-the professor said slowly , as [they]1910-they sat down on the old seat , on [the terrace]1680-the terrace . “ [I]4071-the professor have felt that [you]211-hadria would understand the whole sad story , and [I]4071-the professor hoped that some day [you]211-hadria would know it . ”[4071-the professor] [He]4071-the professor paused and then added , “ It has often been a comfort to [me]4071-the professor to remember that [you]211-hadria were in [the world]334-the world , for it made [me]4071-the professor feel less lonely . [I]4071-the professor felt in [you]211-hadria some new — what can [I]4071-the professor call it ? instinct , impulse , inspiration , which ran [you]211-hadria straight against all the hardest stone walls that intersect the pathways of [this ridiculous old world]1517-this ridiculous old world . And , strange to say , it is the very element in [you]211-hadria that sets [you]211-hadria at loggerheads with [others]432-others , that enabled [me]4071-the professor to understand [you]211-hadria . ”[4071-the professor] [Hadria]211-hadria looked bewildered . “ To tell [you]211-hadria the truth , [I]211-hadria have always wondered why [women]606-women have never felt as [I]211-hadria am sure [you]211-hadria feel towards life . [You]211-hadria remember that day at [Dunaghee]1-dunaghee when [you]211-hadria were so annoyed at [my]211-hadria guessing [your]211-hadria thoughts . They were unmistakeable to one who shared them . [Your]211-hadria sex has always been a riddle to [me]211-hadria ; there seemed to be something abject in [their]606-women nature , even among [the noblest of [them]606-women]5148-the noblest of them . While [I]211-hadria think [you]211-hadria are [the least simple woman [I]211-hadria ever met]5149-the least simple woman i ever met , [you]211-hadria are to [me]211-hadria the easiest to understand . ”[211-hadria] “ And yet [I]211-hadria remember [your]211-hadria telling [me]211-hadria the exact contrary , ”[211-hadria] said [Hadria]211-hadria . “ That was before [I]211-hadria had caught the connecting thread . Had [I]211-hadria been [a woman]3753-a woman , [I]211-hadria believe that life and [my]211-hadria place in it would have affected [me]211-hadria exactly as it affects [you]211-hadria . ”[211-hadria] [Hadria]211-hadria coloured over cheek and brow . It was so strange , so startling , so delicious to find , for the first time in [her]211-hadria life , this intimate sympathy . “ [I]1912-i wish [[my]1912-i wife]1390-my wife had possessed [your]211-hadria friendship , ”[1912-i] [he]1912-i said . “ [I]1912-i believe [you]211-hadria would have saved [us]5152-us . ”[1912-i] [He]1912-i passed [his]1912-i hands over [his]1912-i brow , looking round at the closed windows of [the drawing - room]737-the drawing - room . “ [I]1912-i almost feel as if [she]1390-my wife were near [us]5152-us now on [this old terrace]5153-this old terrace that [she]1390-my wife loved so . [She]1390-my wife planted these roses [herself]1390-my wife — how they have grown ! ”[1912-i] They were white cluster roses and yellow banksias , which had strayed far along the balustrade , clambering among the stone pillars . “ [You]211-hadria doubtless know the bare facts of [her]1390-my wife life , but nothing is so misleading as bare fact . [[My]211-hadria wife]1390-my wife was [one of the positive natures , capable of great nobility]5155-one of the positive natures , capable of great nobility , but liable to glaring error and sin ! [She]1390-my wife held ideas passionately . [She]1390-my wife had the old barbaric notion that [a husband]512-a husband was [a sort of master]5157-a sort of master , and must assert [his]512-a husband authority and rights . It was the result of [her]1390-my wife training . [I]211-hadria saw that a great development was before [her]1390-my wife . [I]211-hadria pleased [myself]211-hadria with the thought of watching and helping it . [She]1390-my wife was built on a grand scale . To set [her]1390-my wife free from prejudice , from [her]1390-my wife injustice to [herself]1390-my wife , from [her]1390-my wife dependence on [me]211-hadria to teach [her]1390-my wife to breathe deep with those big lungs of [hers]1390-my wife and think bravely with that capacious brain : that was [my]211-hadria dream . [I]211-hadria hoped to hear [her]1390-my wife say to [me]211-hadria some day , what [I]211-hadria fear [no woman]5158-no woman has yet been able to say to [[her]1390-my wife husband]553-her husband , ‘ The day of [our]5160-our marriage was the birthday of [my]211-hadria freedom . ’ ”[211-hadria] [Hadria]211-hadria drew a long breath . It seemed to overwhelm [her]211-hadria that [a man]3704-a man , even [the Professor]4071-the professor , could utter such a sentiment . All the old hereditary instincts of conquest and ownership appeared to be utterly dead in [him]3704-a man . No wonder [he]3704-a man had found life a lonely pilgrimage ! [He]3704-a man lived before [his]3704-a man time . [[His]3704-a man wife]573-his wife had taunted [him]3704-a man because [he]3704-a man would not treat [her]573-his wife as [his]3704-a man legal property , or rule [her]573-his wife through the claims and opportunities that popular sentiment assigned to [him]3704-a man . When [a woman as generous as [himself]3704-a man]1917-a woman as generous as himself , as just , as gentle - hearted , had appeared on the horizon of [the world]334-the world , the advent of a nobler social order might be hoped for . [The two]4880-the two were necessary for the new era . Then , not only imagination , but [cold reason]196-cold reason [herself]211-hadria grew eloquent with promises . “ It was in [there]571-there , in [the old drawing - room]4723-the old drawing - room , where [we]5163-we had sat together evening after evening , that [they]5164-they found [her]211-hadria dead , [the very type of all that is brilliant and exquisite and living]5165-the very type of all that is brilliant and exquisite and living . To [me]211-hadria [she]211-hadria was everything . All [my]211-hadria personal happiness was centred in [her]211-hadria . [I]211-hadria cared for nothing so long as [she]211-hadria was in the same world as [myself]211-hadria , and [I]211-hadria might love [her]211-hadria . In the darkness that followed , [I]211-hadria was brought face to face with the most terrible problems of human fate . [I]211-hadria had troubled [myself]211-hadria but little about the question of the survival of the personality after death ; [I]211-hadria had been pre - occupied with life . Now [I]211-hadria realized out of what human longings and what human desperation [our]5163-we religions are built . For one gleam of hope that [we]5163-we should meet again — what would [I]211-hadria not have given ? But it never came . The trend of [my]211-hadria thought made all such hopes impossible . [I]211-hadria have grown charier of the word ‘ impossible ’ now . [We]5163-we know so infinitesimally little . [I]211-hadria had to learn to live on comfortless . All that was strongly personal in [me]211-hadria died . All care about [myself]211-hadria went out suddenly , as in other cases [I]211-hadria think it goes out slowly , beaten down by the continued buffetings of life . [I]211-hadria gave [myself]211-hadria to [my]211-hadria work , and then a curious decentralizing process took place . [I]211-hadria ceased to be the point round which [the world]334-the world revolved , in [my]211-hadria own consciousness . [We]5163-we all start [our]5163-we career as pivots , if [I]211-hadria am not mistaken . [The world]334-the world span , and [I]211-hadria , in [my]211-hadria capacity of atomic part , span with it . [I]211-hadria mean that this was a continuous , not an occasional state of consciousness . After that came an unexpected peace . ”[211-hadria] “ [You]1920-you have travelled a long and hard road to find it ! ”[211-hadria] cried [Hadria]211-hadria . “ Not a unique fate , ”[1920-you] [he]1920-you said with a smile . “ It must be a terrible process that quite kills the personal in one , it is so strong . With [me]1920-you the element is clamorous . ”[1920-you] “ It has its part to play . ”[211-hadria] “ Surely [the gods]812-the gods must be jealous of [human beings]4313-human beings . Why did [they]812-the gods destroy the germ of such happiness as [you]1920-you might have had ? ”[1920-you] “ The stern old law holds for ever ; wrong and error have to be expiated . ”[4071-the professor] [The Professor]4071-the professor traced the history of [[[his]4071-the professor wife]573-his wife 's family]1923-his wife 's family , shewing the gradual gathering of Fate to its culmination in the tragedy of [her]573-his wife short life . [[Her]573-his wife father]609-her father and [grandfather]1925-grandfather had both been [men of violent and tyrannical temper]1926-men of violent and tyrannical temper , and tradition gave the same character to [[their]1926-men of violent and tyrannical temper forefathers]1927-their forefathers . [[Eleanor]197-helen 's mother]1928-eleanor 's mother was [one of [the meek and saintly women who almost invariably fall to the lot of [overbearing men]1931-overbearing men]1930-the meek and saintly women who almost invariably fall to the lot of overbearing men]1929-one of the meek and saintly women who almost invariably fall to the lot of overbearing men . [She]1928-eleanor 's mother had made a virtue of submitting to tyranny , and even to downright cruelty , thus almost repeating the story of [[her]1928-eleanor 's mother equally meek predecessor , of whose ill - treatment stories were still current in [the district]714-the district]1932-her equally meek predecessor , of whose ill - treatment stories were still current in the district . “ When death put an end to [their]1926-men of violent and tyrannical temper wretchedness , one would suppose that the evil of [their]1926-men of violent and tyrannical temper lives was worked out and over , but it was not so . [The Erinnys]198-the erinnys were still unsatisfied . [[My]211-hadria poor wife]5170-my poor wife became the victim of [their]198-the erinnys fury . And every new light that science throws upon human life shews that this must be so . [The old Greeks]1633-the old greeks saw that unconscious evil - doing is punished as well as that which is conscious . [These poor unselfish women]5172-these poor unselfish women , piling up [their]5172-these poor unselfish women own supposed merit , at the expense of the character of [[their]5172-these poor unselfish women tyrants]5173-their tyrants , laid up a store of misery for [[their]5172-these poor unselfish women descendant]5174-their descendant , [[my]211-hadria unhappy wife]5175-my unhappy wife . Imagine the sort of training and tradition that [she]5175-my unhappy wife had to contend with ; [[her]5175-my unhappy wife mother]520-her mother ignorant and supine , [[her]5175-my unhappy wife father]609-her father violent , bigoted , almost brutal . [Eleanor]197-helen 's nature was obscured and distorted by it . Having inherited the finer and stronger qualities of [[her]5175-my unhappy wife father]609-her father 's race , with much of its violence , [she]5175-my unhappy wife was going through a struggle at the time of [our]5179-our marriage : training , native vigour and [nobility]5180-nobility all embroiled in a desperate civil war . It was too much . There is no doubt as to the ultimate issue , but the struggle killed [her]5175-my unhappy wife . It is a common story : a character militant which meets destruction in the struggle for life . The past evil pursues and throttles the present good . ”[211-hadria] “ This takes away the last consolation from [women who have been forced to submit to evil conditions]5181-women who have been forced to submit to evil conditions , ”[211-hadria] said [Hadria]211-hadria . “ It is the truth , ”[4071-the professor] said [the Professor]4071-the professor . “ [The Erinnys]198-the erinnys are [no mere fancy of the Greek mind]5182-no mere fancy of the greek mind . [They]198-the erinnys are symbols of an awful fact of life that [no one]383-no one can afford to ignore . ”[4071-the professor] “ What insensate fools [we]5179-our all are ! ”[211-hadria] [Hadria]211-hadria exclaimed . “ [I]211-hadria mean [women]606-women . ”[211-hadria] [The Professor]4071-the professor made no polite objection to the statement . As [they]1936-they were wending [their]1936-they way towards [the Red House]4718-the red house , [the Professor]4071-the professor reminded [[his]4071-the professor companion]4118-his companion of the old friendship that had existed between [them]1936-they , ever since [Hadria]211-hadria was [a little girl]1940-a little girl . [He]4071-the professor watched [her]211-hadria career with the deepest interest and anxiety . [He]4071-the professor always believed that [she]211-hadria would give some good gift to [the world]334-the world . And [he]4071-the professor still believed it . Like [the rest of [us]1943-us]1660-the rest of us , [she]211-hadria needed sympathy at the right moment . “ [We]1943-us need to feel that there is [someone who believes in [us]1943-us , in [our]1943-us good faith , in [our]1943-us good will]5185-someone who believes in us , in our good faith , in our good will , [one who will not judge according to outward success or failure]5186-one who will not judge according to outward success or failure . Remember , ”[4071-the professor] [he]4071-the professor said , “ that [I]4071-the professor have that unbounded faith in [you]211-hadria . Nothing can move it . It takes more energy to get the dinner delayed for a quarter of an hour in [most well - regulated houses]5190-most well - regulated houses , or some slight change in routine , than to alter a frontier , or pass an Act of Parliament . ”[109-valeria] [Hadria]211-hadria laughed . “ Until [you]109-valeria discovered this by personal inconvenience , [you]109-valeria always scolded [me]211-hadria for [my]211-hadria disposition to jeer at the domestic scheme . ”[211-hadria] “ It is a little geometrical , ”[109-valeria] [Valeria]109-valeria admitted . “ Geometrical ! It is like a gigantic ordnance map palmed off on one instead of a real landscape . ”[109-valeria] “ Come now , to be just , say [an Italian garden]5191-an italian garden . ”[211-hadria] “ That flatters it , but the simile will do . [The eye]5192-the eye sees to the end of every path , and knows that it leads to nothing . ”[211-hadria] “ Ah ! dear [Hadria]211-hadria , but [all the pathways of [the world]334-the world]5193-all the pathways of the world have that very same goal . ”[211-hadria] “ At least some of them have the good taste to wind a little , and thus disguise the fact . And think of the wild flowers [one]5195-one may gather by the wayside in [some forest track]5196-some forest track , or among [the mountain passes]5197-the mountain passes ; but in these prim alleys what natural thing can one know ? [Brain]199-brain and heart grow tame and clipped to match the hedges , or take on grotesque shapes — ”[211-hadria] “ That [one]329-one must guard against . ”[211-hadria] “ Oh , [I]211-hadria am sick of guarding against things . To be always warding off evil , is an evil in itself . Better let it come . ”[211-hadria] [Valeria]109-valeria looked at [[her]109-valeria companion]3995-her companion anxiously . “ [One]329-one knows how twirling round in a circle makes [one]329-one giddy , or following the same path stupifies . How does the polar bear feel , [I]109-valeria wonder , after [he]5201-he has walked up and down in [his]5201-he cage for years and years ? ”[109-valeria] “ Used to it , [I]109-valeria imagine , ”[109-valeria] said [Valeria]109-valeria . “ But before [he]5201-he gets used to it , that is the bad time . And then it is all so confusing — ”[109-valeria] [Hadria]211-hadria sat on the low parapet of [the terrace at [the Priory]31-the priory]1945-the terrace at the priory . [Valeria]109-valeria had a place on the topmost step , where the sun had been beating all the morning . [Hadria]211-hadria had taken off [her]211-hadria hat to enjoy the warmth . The long sprays of the roses were blown across [her]211-hadria now and then . Once , a thorn had left a mark of blood upon [her]211-hadria hand . [Valeria]109-valeria gathered a spray , and nodded slowly . “ [I]109-valeria do n't want to allow emotion to get the better of [me]109-valeria , [Valeria]109-valeria . [I]109-valeria do n't want to run rank like some overgrown weed , and so [I]109-valeria dread the accumulation of emotion — emotion that has never had a good explosive utterance . [One]329-one has to be so discreet in [these Italian gardens]5203-these italian gardens ; [no one]383-no one shouts or says ‘ damn . ’ ”[109-valeria] “ Ah ! [you]109-valeria naturally feel out of [your]109-valeria element . ”[211-hadria] [Hadria]211-hadria laughed . “ It 's all very well to take that superior tone . [You]109-valeria do n't reside on an ordnance map . ”[211-hadria] There was a pause . [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria seemed lost in thought . “ It is this dead silence that oppresses [one]329-one , this hushed endurance of the travail of life . How do [these women]1726-these women stand it ? ”[109-valeria] [Valeria]109-valeria presently woke up , and admitted that to live in [an English village]1946-an english village would drive [her]109-valeria out of [her]109-valeria mind in a week . “ And yet , [Valeria]109-valeria , [you]109-valeria have often professed to envy [me]109-valeria , because [I]109-valeria had what [you]109-valeria called a place in life — as if [a place in [Craddock Dene]22-craddock dene]5207-a place in craddock dene were the same thing ! ”[109-valeria] “ It is well that [you]109-valeria do not mean all [you]109-valeria say . ”[109-valeria] “ Or say all [I]109-valeria mean . ”[109-valeria] [Valeria]109-valeria laid [her]109-valeria hand on [Hadria]211-hadria 's with wistful tenderness . “ [I]109-valeria do n't think [anyone]806-anyone will ever quite understand [you]109-valeria , [Hadria]211-hadria . ”[109-valeria] “ Including perhaps [myself]109-valeria . [I]109-valeria sometimes fancy that when it became necessary to provide [me]109-valeria with a disposition , the material had run out , for the moment , nothing being left but a few remnants of [other people]3849-other people 's characters ; so a living handful of these was taken up , roughly welded together , and then the mixture was sent whirling into space , to boil and sputter itself out as best it might . ”[109-valeria] [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria turned to [[her]109-valeria companion]3995-her companion . “ [I]109-valeria see that [you]3995-her companion are incongruously situated , but do n't [you]3995-her companion think that [you]3995-her companion may be wrong [yourself]3995-her companion ? Do n't [you]3995-her companion think [you]3995-her companion may be making a mistake ? ”[109-valeria] [Hadria]211-hadria was emphatic in assent . “ Not only do [I]211-hadria think [I]211-hadria may be wrong , but [I]211-hadria do n't see how — unless by pure chance — [I]211-hadria can be anything else . For [I]211-hadria ca n't discover what is right . [I]211-hadria see [women]606-women all round [me]211-hadria actuated by this frenzied sense of duty ; [I]211-hadria see [them]606-women toiling submissively at [their]606-women eternal treadmill ; occupying [their]606-women best years in the business of filling [[their]606-women nurseries]5211-their nurseries ; losing [their]606-women youth , narrowing [their]606-women intelligence , ruining [[their]606-women husbands]5212-their husbands , and clouding [their]606-women very moral sense at last . Well , [I]211-hadria know that such conduct is supposed to be right and virtuous . But [I]211-hadria ca n't see it . It impresses [me]211-hadria simply as stupid and degrading . And from [my]211-hadria narrow little point of observation , the more [I]211-hadria see of life , the more hopelessly involved become all questions of right and wrong where [our]5213-our confounded sex is concerned . ”[211-hadria] “ Why ? Because the standards are changing , ”[109-valeria] asserted [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria . “ Because — look , [Valeria]109-valeria , [our]5213-our present relation to life is in itself an injury , an insult — [you]5214-you have never seriously denied that — and how can one make for [oneself]5215-oneself a moral code that has to lay its foundation - stone in that very injury ? And if one lays [one]329-one 's foundation - stone in open ground beyond , then [one]329-one 's code is out of touch with present fact , and [one]329-one 's morality consists in sheer revolt all along the line . The whole matter is in confusion . [You]5214-you have to accept [Mrs. Walker]162-mrs. walker 's and [Mrs. Gordon]91-mrs. gordon 's view of the case , plainly and simply , or [you]5214-you get off into a sort of morass and blunder into quicksands . ”[109-valeria] “ Then what happens ? ”[211-hadria] “ That 's just what [I]211-hadria do n't know . That 's just why [I]211-hadria say that [I]211-hadria am probably wrong , because , in this transition period , there seems to be no clear right . ”[211-hadria] “ To cease to believe in right and wrong would be to founder morally , altogether , ”[109-valeria] [Valeria]109-valeria warned . “ [I]109-valeria know , and yet [I]109-valeria begin to realize how true it is that there is no such thing as absolute right or wrong . It is related to the case and the moment . ”[109-valeria] “ This leads up to some desperate deed or other , [Hadria]211-hadria , ”[4123-her friend] cried [[her]109-valeria friend]4123-her friend , “ [I]4123-her friend have feared it , or hoped it , [I]4123-her friend scarcely know which , for some time . But [you]211-hadria alarm [me]4123-her friend to - day . ”[4123-her friend] “ If [I]109-valeria believed in the efficacy of a desperate deed , [Valeria]109-valeria , [I]109-valeria should not chafe as [I]109-valeria do , against the conditions of the present scheme of things . If [individuals]5219-individuals could find a remedy for [themselves]5219-individuals , with a little courage and will , there would be less occasion to growl . ”[109-valeria] “ But can [they]5219-individuals not ? ”[109-valeria] “ Can [they]5219-individuals ? ”[211-hadria] asked [Hadria]211-hadria . “ [A woman without means of livelihood]5220-a woman without means of livelihood , breaks away from [her]5220-a woman without means of livelihood moorings — well , it is as if [a child]754-a child were to fall into the midst of some gigantic machinery that is going at full speed . [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria admitted that success was rare in the present delirious state of competition . [Individuals here and there]1949-individuals here and there pulled through . “ [I]1949-individuals here and there told [you]109-valeria years ago that [Nature]120-nature had chosen [our]5222-we sex for ill - usage . Mind and will and [every human faculty]5234-every human faculty may die , but [they]5233-they shall not drown , in the usual applauded fashion , in seas of tepid , bubbling , up - swelling instinct . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald approached [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley and [Joseph Fleming]159-joseph fleming . [Hadria]211-hadria knew by some instinct that [the Professor]4071-the professor had been waiting for an opportunity to speak to [her]211-hadria . As [he]4071-the professor drew near , a feeling of intense enmity arose within [her]211-hadria , which reached its highest pitch when [he]4071-the professor addressed [her]211-hadria in a fine , low - toned voice of peculiarly fascinating quality . Every instinct rose up as if in warning . [He]4071-the professor sat down beside [her]211-hadria , and began to talk about [the Priory]1664-the priory and [its]1664-the priory history . [His]4071-the professor ability was obvious , even in [his]4071-the professor choice of words and [his]4071-the professor selection of incidents . [He]4071-the professor had the power of making dry archæological facts almost dramatic . [His]4071-the professor speech differed from that of [most men]1974-most men , in the indefinable manner wherein excellence differs from mediocrity . Yet [Hadria]211-hadria was glad to notice some equally indefinable lack , corresponding perhaps to the gap in [his]4071-the professor consciousness that [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton had come upon in [their]1975-their discussions on the general principles of art . What was it ? A certain stilted , unreal quality ? Scarcely . Words refused to fit themselves to the evasive form . Something that suggested the term “ second class , ”[1976-a master of the ambiguous] though whether it were the manner or the substance that was responsible for the impression , was difficult to say . Sometimes [his]4071-the professor words allowed two possible interpretations to be put upon a sentence . [He]4071-the professor was [a master of the ambiguous]1976-a master of the ambiguous . Obviously it was not lack of skill that produced the double - faced phrases . [He]4071-the professor did not leave [[his]4071-the professor listeners]1015-his listeners long in doubt as to [his]4071-the professor personal history . [He]4071-the professor enjoyed talking about [himself]4071-the professor . [He]4071-the professor was [a Professor of archæology]1978-a professor of archæology , and had written various learned books on the subject . But [his]4071-the professor studies had by no means been confined to the one theme . History had also interested [him]4071-the professor profoundly . [He]4071-the professor had published a work on [the old houses of [England]14-england]1979-the old houses of england . [The Priory]1664-the priory figured among [them]1979-the old houses of england . It was not difficult to discover from the conversation of [this singular man]1981-this singular man , whose subtle and secretive instincts were contradicted , at times , by a strange inconsequent frankness , that [his]4071-the professor genuine feeling for the picturesque was accompanied by an equally strong predilection for the appurtenances of wealth and splendour ; [his]4071-the professor love of great names and [estates]1982-estates being almost of the calibre of [the housemaid]1983-the housemaid 's passion for lofty personages in [her]1983-the housemaid penny periodical . [He]4071-the professor seemed to be [a man of keen and cunning ability]1984-a man of keen and cunning ability , who studied and played upon the passions and weaknesses of [[his]4071-the professor fellows]951-his fellows , possibly for [their]951-his fellows good , but always as [a magician]518-a magician might deal with the beings subject to [his]4071-the professor power . By what strange lapse did [he]4071-the professor thus naïvely lay [himself]4071-the professor open to [their]951-his fellows smiles ? [Hadria]211-hadria was amused at [his]4071-the professor occasional impulse of egotistic frankness ( or what appeared to be such ) , when [he]4071-the professor would solemnly analyse [his]4071-the professor own character , admitting [his]4071-the professor instinct to deceive with an engaging and scholarly candour . [His]4071-the professor penetrating eyes kept a watch upon [[his]4071-the professor audience]1987-his audience . [His]4071-the professor very simplicity seemed to be guarded by [his]4071-the professor keenness . [Hadria]211-hadria chafed under [his]4071-the professor persistent effort to attract and interest [her]211-hadria . [She]211-hadria gave a little inward shiver on finding that there was a vague , unaccountable , and unpleasant fascination in the personality of [the man]3754-the man . It was not charm , it was nothing that inspired admiration ; it rather inspired curiosity and stirred the spirit of research , a spirit which evidently animated [himself]4071-the professor . [She]211-hadria felt that , in order to investigate the workings of [her]211-hadria mind and [her]211-hadria heart , [the Professor]4071-the professor would have coolly pursued the most ruthless psychical experiments , no matter at what cost of anguish to [herself]211-hadria . In the interests of science and humanity , [the learned Professor]1990-the learned professor would certainly not hesitate to make [one wretched individual]1991-one wretched individual agonize . [His]4071-the professor appeal to the intellect was stimulatingly strong ; it was like a stinging wind , that made one walk at a reckless pace , and brought the blood tingling through every vein . That intellectual force could alone explain the fact of [his]4071-the professor being counted by [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue as [a friend]727-a friend . Even then it was a puzzling friendship . Could it be that to [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue , [he]116-professor fortescue shewed only [his]116-professor fortescue best side ? [His]116-professor fortescue manner was more respectful towards [[his]116-professor fortescue colleague]1971-his colleague than towards [other men]1807-other men , but even with [him]116-professor fortescue [he]116-professor fortescue was irreverent in [his]116-professor fortescue heart , as towards [mankind]1102-mankind in general . To [Hadria]211-hadria [he]116-professor fortescue spoke of [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue with enthusiasm — praising [his]116-professor fortescue great power , [his]116-professor fortescue generosity , [his]116-professor fortescue genial qualities , and [his]116-professor fortescue uprightness ; then [he]116-professor fortescue laughed at [him]116-professor fortescue as [a modern Don Quixote]1996-a modern don quixote , and sneered at [his]116-professor fortescue efforts to save animal suffering when [he]116-professor fortescue might have made a name that would never be forgotten , if [he]116-professor fortescue pursued a more fruitful branch of research . [Hadria]211-hadria remarked that [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald 's last sentence had added the crowning dignity to [his]116-professor fortescue eulogium . [He]116-professor fortescue glanced at [her]211-hadria , as if taking [her]211-hadria measure . “ [Fortescue]116-professor fortescue , ”[116-professor fortescue] [he]116-professor fortescue called out , “ [I]116-professor fortescue envy [you]116-professor fortescue [[your]116-professor fortescue champion]5277-your champion . [You]116-professor fortescue point , [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley , to lofty altitudes . [I]116-professor fortescue , as [a mere man]856-a mere man , can not pretend to scale [them]5279-them . ”[116-professor fortescue] Then [he]116-professor fortescue proceeded to bring down feminine loftiness with virile reason . “ In [this world]430-this world , where there are so many other evils to combat , [one]329-one feels that it is more rational to attack the more important first . ”[116-professor fortescue] “ Ah ! there is nothing like an evil to bolster up an evil , ”[116-professor fortescue] cried [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue ; “ the argument never fails . Every abuse may find shelter behind it . The slave trade , for instance ; have [we]5282-our not white slavery in [our]5282-our midst ? How inconsistent to trouble about [negroes]5283-negroes till [[our]5282-our own people]5284-our own people are truly free ! Wife - beating ? Sad ; but then [children]626-children are often shamefully ill - used . Wait till [they]626-children are fully protected before fussing about [wives]1404-wives . Protect [children]626-children ? [Foolish knight - errant]5288-foolish knight - errant , when [you]116-professor fortescue ought to know that drunkenness is at the root of these crimes ! Sweep away this curse , before thinking of [the children]667-the children . As for animals , how can [any rational person]5290-any rational person consider [their]626-children sufferings , when there are [men]3698-men , [women]606-women , and [children with wrongs to be redressed]5293-children with wrongs to be redressed ? ”[116-professor fortescue] [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald laughed . “ [[My]181-professor theobald dear]3722-my dear [Fortescue]116-professor fortescue , [I]181-professor theobald knew [you]116-professor fortescue would have some ingenious excuse for [your]116-professor fortescue amiable weaknesses . ”[181-professor theobald] “ It is easier to find epithets than answers , [Theobald]181-professor theobald , ”[4071-the professor] said [the Professor]4071-the professor with a smile . “ [I]4071-the professor confess [I]4071-the professor wonder at [a man of [your]116-professor fortescue logical power]5295-a man of your logical power being taken in with this cheap argument , if argument it can be called . ”[4071-the professor] “ It is [my]181-professor theobald attachment to logic that makes [me]181-professor theobald crave for consistency , ”[181-professor theobald] said [Theobald]181-professor theobald , not over pleased at [[his]181-professor theobald friend]4122-his friend 's attack . [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue stared in surprise . “ But do [you]116-professor fortescue really mean to tell [me]116-professor fortescue that [you]116-professor fortescue think it logical to excuse one abuse by pointing to another ? ”[116-professor fortescue] “ [I]181-professor theobald think that while there are [ill - used women]5296-ill - used women and [children]626-children , it is certainly inconsistent to consider animals , ”[181-professor theobald] said [Theobald]181-professor theobald . “ It does not occur to [you]116-professor fortescue that the spirit in [man that permits abuse of power over animals]5298-man that permits abuse of power over animals is precisely the same devil - inspired spirit that expresses itself in cruelty towards [children]626-children . Ah , ”[116-professor fortescue] continued [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue , shaking [his]116-professor fortescue head , “ then [you]116-professor fortescue really are one of [the many who help wrong to breed wrong , and suffering to foster suffering]5300-the many who help wrong to breed wrong , and suffering to foster suffering , all [the world]334-the world over . It is [you]116-professor fortescue and those who reason as [you]116-professor fortescue reason , who give to [our]5302-our miseries [their]626-children terrible vitality . What arguments has evil ever given to evil ! What shelter and succour cruelty offers eternally to cruelty ! ”[116-professor fortescue] [I]0-i ca n't attempt to combat this hobby of [yours]116-professor fortescue , [Fortescue]116-professor fortescue . ” “[116-professor fortescue] Again [a be - littling epithet in place of an argument]1999-a be - littling epithet in place of an argument ! But [I]0-i know of old that on this subject [your]116-professor fortescue intellectual acumen deserts [you]116-professor fortescue , as it deserts nearly [all men]2000-all men . [You]116-professor fortescue sink suddenly to lower spiritual rank , and employ reasoning that [you]116-professor fortescue would laugh to scorn in connection with every other topic . ” “[116-professor fortescue] [You]116-professor fortescue seem bent on crushing [me]0-i , ” exclaimed [Theobald]181-professor theobald . “[116-professor fortescue] And [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley enjoys seeing [me]0-i mangled . Talk about cruelty to animals ! [I]0-i call this cold - blooded devilry ! [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley , come to [my]0-i rescue ! ” “[154-mrs. temperley] So long as other forms of cruelty can be instanced , [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald , [I]0-i do n't see how , on [your]181-professor theobald own shewing , [you]181-professor theobald can expect [any consistent person]2001-any consistent person to raise a finger to help [you]181-professor theobald , ” [Hadria]211-hadria returned . [Theobald]181-professor theobald laughed . “[2001-any consistent person] But [I]0-i consider [myself]0-i too important and valuable to be made the subject of this harsh treatment . ” “[0-i] That is for [others]432-others to decide . If it affords [us]2003-we amusement to torment [you]181-professor theobald , and amusement benefits [our]2003-we nerves and digestion , how can [you]181-professor theobald justly object ? [We]2003-we must consider the greatest good of the greatest number ; and [we]2003-we are twice as numerous as [you]181-professor theobald . ” “[181-professor theobald] [You]181-professor theobald are delicious ! ” [he]181-professor theobald exclaimed . [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley 's manner stiffened . Acute as [the Professor]4071-the professor was in many directions , [he]4071-the professor did not appear to notice the change . [His]4071-the professor own manner was not above criticism . “[181-professor theobald] It is strange , ” said [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton , in speaking of [him]2004-him afterwards to [Hadria]211-hadria , “[181-professor theobald] it is strange that [his]2004-him cleverness does not come to the rescue ; but so far from that , [I]0-i think it leads [him]2004-him a wild dance over boggy ground , like some will - o'-the - wisp , but for whose freakish allurements [the good man]1126-the good man might have trodden a quiet and inoffensive way . ” The only means of procuring the indispensable afternoon tea was to go on to [the Red House]4718-the red house , which [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley proposed that [they]2007-they should all do . “[1126-the good man] And is there no shaking [your]2004-him decision about [the Priory]1664-the priory , [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald ? ” [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton asked as [they]2007-they descended the steps . [The Professor]4071-the professor 's quick glance sought [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley 's before [he]4071-the professor answered . “[0-i] [I]0-i confess to feeling less heroic this afternoon . ” “[0-i] Oh , good ! [We]2007-they may perhaps have [you]2004-him for [a neighbour]2008-a neighbour after all . ” [HADRIA]211-hadria tried to avoid [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald , but [he]181-professor theobald was not easily avoided . [She]211-hadria frequently met [him]181-professor theobald in [[her]211-hadria walks]5306-her walks . The return of spring had tempted [her]211-hadria to resume [her]211-hadria old habit of rising with the sun . But [she]211-hadria found , what [she]211-hadria had feared , that [her]211-hadria strength had departed , and [she]211-hadria as fatigued instead of invigorated , as of yore . [She]211-hadria did not regard this loss in a resigned spirit . Resignation was certainly not [her]211-hadria strong point . [[The vicar]4965-the vicar 's wife]4966-the vicar 's wife and [[the doctor]1471-the doctor 's wife]5310-the doctor 's wife and [the rest of [the neighbours]1469-the neighbours]5311-the rest of the neighbours compared [their]5311-the rest of the neighbours woes and weariness over five o'clock tea , and these appeared so many and so severe that [Hadria]211-hadria felt half ashamed to count [hers]211-hadria at all . Yet why lower the altars of [the sane goddess]5313-the sane goddess because [her]5313-the sane goddess shrine was deserted ? Health was health , though [all the women of [England]14-england]5314-all the women of england were [confirmed invalids]5315-confirmed invalids . And with nothing less ought [reasonable creatures]5316-reasonable creatures to be satisfied . As for taking enfeeblement as a natural dispensation , [she]211-hadria would as soon regard delirium tremens in that light . [She]211-hadria chafed fiercely against the loss of that blessed sense of well - being and overflowing health , that [she]211-hadria used to have , in the old days . [She]211-hadria resented the nerve - weariness , the fatigue that [she]211-hadria was now more conscious of than ever , with the coming of the spring . The impulse of creative energy broke forth in [her]211-hadria . The pearly mornings and the birds ' songs stirred every instinct of expression . The outburst did not receive its usual check . The influences of disenchantment were counteracted by [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue 's presence . [His]116-professor fortescue sympathy was marvellous in its penetration , brimming the cold hollows of [her]211-hadria spirit , as [a flooded river]5317-a flooded river fills the tiniest chinks and corners about [its]5317-a flooded river arid banks . [He]116-professor fortescue called forth all [her]211-hadria natural buoyancy and [her]211-hadria exulting sense of life , which was precisely the element which charged [her]211-hadria sadness with such a fierce electric quality , when [she]211-hadria became possessed by it , as a cloud by storm . [Valeria]109-valeria too was roused by the season . “[2008-a neighbour] What a parable it all is , as old as [the earth]2009-the earth , and as fresh , each new year , as if [a messenger - angel]2010-a messenger - angel had come straight from [heaven]4276-heaven , in [[his]2010-a messenger - angel home - spun of young green]2012-his home - spun of young green , to tell [us]2013-they that all is well . ” If [Hadria]211-hadria met [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald in [her]211-hadria rambles , [she]211-hadria always cut short [her]211-hadria intended walk . [She]211-hadria and [Valeria]109-valeria with [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue wandered together , far and wide . [They]2013-they watched the daily budding greenery , the gleams of daffodils among [their]2013-they sword - blades of leaves , the pushing of sheaths and heads through the teeming soil , the bursts of sunshine and the absurd childish little gushes of rain , skimming [the green country]5318-the green country like a frown . “[2010-a messenger - angel] Truly a time for joy and idleness . ” “[2010-a messenger - angel] If only , ” said [Hadria]211-hadria , when [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald thus grew enthusiastic on the subject , “[2010-a messenger - angel] if only [[my]0-i cook]2014-my cook had not given a month 's notice . ” [She]211-hadria would not second [his]181-professor theobald mood , be it what it might . Each day , as [they]2013-they passed along [the lanes]5319-the lanes , the pale green had spread , like fire , on the hedges , caught the chestnuts , with their fat buds shining in the sun , which already was releasing the close - packed leaflets . [Hadria]211-hadria ( apparently out of sheer devilry , said [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald ) kept up a running commentary on the season , and on [her]211-hadria hapless position , bound to be off on the chase for [a cook]5320-a cook at this moment of festival . Nor was this all . Crockery , pots and pans , clothes for [the children]667-the children , clothes for [herself]211-hadria , were urgently needed , and [no experienced person]5322-no experienced person , [she]211-hadria declared , could afford to regard the matter as simple because it was trivial . “[2014-my cook] One of the ghastliest mistakes in this trivial and laborious world . ” [Valeria]109-valeria thought that [cooks]5323-cooks had simply to be advertised for , and [they]5323-cooks came . “[2014-my cook] What naïveté ! ” exclaimed [Hadria]211-hadria . “[197-helen] [Helen]197-helen was persuaded to cross [the seas]2015-the seas from [[her]197-helen Spartan home]2016-her spartan home to set [Troy]37-troy ablaze , and tarnish [her]197-helen fair fame , but it would take [twenty sons of [Priam]202-priam]2017-twenty sons of priam to induce [a damsel]2018-a damsel to come over [dry land]2019-dry land to [Craddock Dene]164-craddock dene , to cook [our]2020-our dinners and retain [her]2018-a damsel character . ” “[2021-you] [You]2021-you would almost imply that [women]606-women do n't so very much care about [[their]606-women characters]2023-their characters , ” said [Valeria]109-valeria . “[606-women] Oh , [they]606-women do ! but sometimes the dulness that [an intelligent society]2024-an intelligent society has ordained as the classic accompaniment to social smiles , gets the better of [a select few]2025-a select few — [Helen]197-helen par exemple . ” It frequently happened that [Hadria]211-hadria and [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria came across [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton and [[her]176-lady engleton guests]5324-her guests , in [the Priory garden]1677-the priory garden . From being accidental , the meetings had become intentional . “[197-helen] [I]0-i like to fancy [we]2020-our are [fugitives]2026-fugitives — like [Boccaccio]203-boccaccio 's merry company — from the plague of [our]2020-our daily prose , to this garden of sweet poetry ! ” cried [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria . [They]2020-our all kindled at the idea . [Valeria]109-valeria made some fanciful laws that [she]109-valeria said were to govern [the little realm]5326-the little realm . [Everyone]3726-everyone might express [himself]3726-everyone freely , and all that [he]3726-everyone said would be held as sacred , as if it were in confidence . To speak ill or slightingly of [anyone]806-anyone , was forbidden . All local and practical topics were to be dropped , as soon as [the moss - grown griffins who guarded [the Garden of Forgetfulness]5330-the garden of forgetfulness]5329-the moss - grown griffins who guarded the garden of forgetfulness were passed . [Hadria]211-hadria was incorrigibly flippant about the banishment of important local subjects . [She]211-hadria said that the kitchen - boiler was out of order , and yet [she]211-hadria had to take part in these highly - cultivated conversations and smile , as [she]211-hadria complained , with that kitchen - boiler gnawing at [her]211-hadria vitals . [She]211-hadria claimed to be set on a level with [the Spartan boy]5331-the spartan boy , if not above [him]5331-the spartan boy . [Valeria]109-valeria might scoff , as those proverbially did who never felt a wound . [Hadria]211-hadria found a certain lack of tender feeling among [the happy few who had no such tragic burdens to sustain]5332-the happy few who had no such tragic burdens to sustain . Not only were [these prosaic subjects banished from within the cincture of the gentle griffins]5333-these prosaic subjects banished from within the cincture of the gentle griffins , but also the suspicions , spites , petty jealousies , vulgar curiosities , and all the indefinable little darts and daggers that fly in the social air , destroying human sympathy and good - will . Each mind could expand freely , no longer on the defensive against the rain of small stabs . There grew up a delicate , and chivalrous code among [the little group who met within [the griffins]5335-the griffins ' territory]5334-the little group who met within the griffins ' territory . “[203-boccaccio] It is not for [us]2027-we to say that , individually , [we]2027-we transcend the average of [educated mortals]2028-educated mortals , ” said [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald , “[203-boccaccio] but [I]0-i do assert that collectively [we]2027-we soar high above that depressing standard . ” [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue observed that whatever might be said about [[their]2027-we own little band]5336-their own little band , it was a strange fact that [bodies of]5337-bodies of [human beings]4313-human beings were able to produce , by union , a condition far above or far below the average of [their]2027-we separate values . “[0-i] There is something chemical and explosive in human relationships , ” [he]116-professor fortescue said . These meetings stood out as a unique experience in the memory of [all who took part in them]5339-all who took part in them . [Chance]204-chance had brought [them]2027-we to pass , and [they]2027-we refused to answer to the call of [a less learned magician]5340-a less learned magician . [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton and [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley alternately sent tea and fruit to [the terrace]1680-the terrace , on the days of meeting , and there [the little company]5342-the little company would spend the afternoon serenely , surrounded by the beauties of [the garden]3867-the garden with [its]3867-the garden enticing avenues , [its]3867-the garden chaunting birds , its flushes of bloom , and its rich delicious scents . “[0-i] Why do [we]2027-we , in the nineteenth century , starve [ourselves]2027-we of these delicate joys ? ” cried [Valeria]109-valeria . “[2027-we] Why do [we]2027-we so seldom leave [our]2027-we stupid pre - occupations and open [our]2027-we souls to the sun , to the spring , to the gentle invitations of [gardens]2029-gardens , to the charm of conversation ? [We]2027-we seem to know nothing of the serenities , the urbanities of life . ” “[2027-we] [We]2027-we live too fast ; [we]2027-we are too much troubled about outward things — [cooks]5323-cooks and [dressmakers]4812-dressmakers , [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley , ” said [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald . “[154-mrs. temperley] [Poor cooks]2032-poor cooks and [dressmakers]4812-dressmakers ! ” murmured [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue , “[154-mrs. temperley] where are [their]2032-poor cooks serenities and urbanities ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i would not deprive [any person]2034-any person of the good things of life , ” cried [Valeria]109-valeria ; “[0-i] but at present , it is only [a few who can appreciate and contribute to the delicate essence]2035-a few who can appreciate and contribute to the delicate essence that [I]0-i speak of . [I]0-i do n't think [one]329-one could expect it of [[one]329-one 's cook]2038-one 's cook , after all . ” “[329-one] [One]329-one is mad to expect anything of [those who have had no chance]2040-those who have had no chance , ” said [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue . “[329-one] That nevertheless [we]2041-us consistently do,—or what amounts to the same thing : [we]2041-us plume [ourselves]2041-us on what chance has enabled [us]2041-us to be and to achieve , as if between [us]2041-us and [the less fortunate]2042-the less fortunate there were some great difference of calibre and merit . Nine times in ten , there is nothing between [us]2041-us but luck . ” “[0-i] Oh , dear , [you]0-i are democratic , [Professor]181-professor theobald ! ” cried [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton . “[0-i] No ; [I]0-i am merely trying to be just . ” “[0-i] To be just [you]0-i must apply [your]0-i theory to [men]3698-men and [women]606-women , as well as to class and class , ” [Valeria]109-valeria suggested . “[0-i] [Mon Dieu]205-mon dieu ! but so [I]0-i do ; so [I]0-i always have done , as soon as [I]0-i was intellectually short - coated . ” “[0-i] And would [you]0-i excuse all [our]2041-us weaknesses on that ground ? ” asked [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton , with a somewhat ingratiating upward gaze of [her]176-lady engleton blue eyes . “[0-i] [I]0-i would account for [them]2045-them as [I]0-i would account for the weaknesses of [my]0-i own sex . As for excusing , the question of moral responsibility is too involved to be decided off - hand . ” The atmosphere of [Griffin - land]38-griffin - land , as [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald called it , while becoming to [his]181-professor theobald character , made [him]181-professor theobald a little recklessly frank at times . [He]181-professor theobald admitted that throughout [his]181-professor theobald varied experience of life , [he]181-professor theobald had found flattery the most powerful weapon in a skilled hand , and that [he]181-professor theobald had never known it fail . [He]181-professor theobald related instances of the signal success which had followed its application with the trowel . [He]181-professor theobald reminded [[his]181-professor theobald listeners]1015-his listeners of [Lord Beaconsfield]206-lord beaconsfield 's famous saying , and chuckled over [the unfortunate woman]5345-the unfortunate woman , “[0-i] plain as a pike - staff , ” who had become [his]181-professor theobald benefactress , in consequence of a discreet allusion to the “[0-i] power of beauty ” and a well - placed sigh . “[4547-the woman] [The woman]4547-the woman must have been [a fool]1606-a fool ! ” said [Joseph Fleming]159-joseph fleming . “[4547-the woman] By no means ; [she]4547-the woman was of brilliant intellect . But praises of that were tame to [her]4547-the woman ; [she]4547-the woman knew [her]4547-the woman force , and was perhaps tired of the solitude it induced . ” [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald laughed mightily at [his]181-professor theobald own sarcasm . “[4547-the woman] But when the whisper of ‘ beauty ’ came stealing to [her]4547-the woman ear ( which was by no means like a shell ) it was surpassing sweet to [her]4547-the woman . [I]0-i think there is no yearning more intense than that of [a clever woman for the triumphs of mere beauty]2048-a clever woman for the triumphs of mere beauty . [She]4547-the woman would give all [her]4547-the woman powers of intellect for the smallest tribute to personal and feminine charm . What is [your]0-i verdict , [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley ? ” [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley supposed that [clever women]5346-clever women had something of human nature in [them]5346-clever women , and valued overmuch what [they]5346-clever women did not possess . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald had perhaps looked for an answer that would have betrayed more of [the speaker]306-the speaker 's secret feelings . “[154-mrs. temperley] It is the fashion , [I]0-i know , ” [he]181-professor theobald said , “[0-i] to regard [woman]3844-woman as an enigma . Now , without professing any unusual acuteness , [I]0-i believe that this is a mistake . [Woman]207-woman is [an enigma]2050-an enigma certainly , because [she]207-woman is human , but that ends it . [Her]207-woman conditions have tended to cultivate in [her]207-woman the power of dissimulation , and the histrionic quality , just as [the peaceful ilex]2051-the peaceful ilex learns to put forth thorns if [you]2052-you expose it to the attacks of devouring cattle . It is this instinct to develop thorns in self - defence , and yet to live a little behind the prickly outposts , that leads to [our]2053-our notion of mystery in [woman]3844-woman 's nature . Let [a man]3704-a man 's subsistence and career be subject to the same powers and chances as the success of [a woman]3753-a woman 's life now hangs on , and see whether [he]3704-a man too does not become [a histrionic enigma]2057-a histrionic enigma . ” [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue observed that [the clergy]5348-the clergy , at times , developed qualities called feminine , because in some respects [their]5348-the clergy conditions resembled those of [women]606-women . [Theobald]181-professor theobald assented enthusiastically to this view . [He]181-professor theobald had [himself]181-professor theobald entered [the church]1115-the church as [a young fellow]5351-a young fellow ( let not [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley look so inconsiderately astonished ) , and had left it on account of being unable to conscientiously subscribe to its tenets . “[0-i] But not before [I]0-i had acquired some severe training in that sort of strategy which is incumbent upon [women]606-women , in the conduct of [their]606-women lives . Whatever [I]0-i might privately think or feel , [[my]0-i office]2059-my office required that [I]0-i should only express that which would be more or less grateful to [[my]0-i hearers]2060-my hearers . ( Is not this [the woman]4547-the woman 's case , in almost every position in life ? ) Even orthodoxy must trip it on tiptoe ; there was always some prejudice , some susceptibility to consider . What was frankness in others was imprudence in [me]0-i ; [other men]1807-other men 's minds might roam at large ; [mine]0-i was tethered , if not in its secret movements , at least in its utterance ; and it is a curious and somewhat sinister law of Nature , that perpetual denial of utterance ends by killing the power or the feeling so held in durance . ” [Hadria]211-hadria coloured . “[0-i] That experience and its effect upon [my]0-i own nature , which has lasted to this day , ” added [Theobald]181-professor theobald , “[0-i] served to increase [my]0-i interest in the fascinating study of character in its relation to environment . ” “[0-i] Ah ! ” exclaimed [Hadria]211-hadria , “[0-i] then [you]0-i do n't believe in the independent power of the human will ? ” “[0-i] Certainly not . To talk of character overcoming circumstance is to talk of an effect without a cause . Yet this phrase is a mere commonplace in [our]2063-our speech . [A man]3704-a man no more overcomes [his]3704-a man circumstance than oxygen overcomes nitrogen when it combines with it to form the air [we]2063-our breathe . If the nitrogen is present , the combination takes place ; but if there is no nitrogen to be had , all the oxygen in [the world]334-the world will not produce [our]2063-our blessed atmosphere ! ” [Joseph Fleming]159-joseph fleming caused a sort of anti - climax by mentioning simply that [he]159-joseph fleming did n't know that any nitrogen was required in the atmosphere . [One]329-one always heard about the oxygen . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald remarked , with a chuckle , that this was one of the uses of polite conversation ; [one]329-one picked up information by the way - side . [Joseph]159-joseph fleming agreed that it was wonderfully instructive , if [the speakers]5354-the speakers were intelligent . “[0-i] That helps , ” said [the Professor]4071-the professor , tapping [Joseph]159-joseph fleming familiarly on the shoulder . “[0-i] When shall [we]2063-our have [our]2063-our next meeting ? ” enquired [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton , when the moment came for parting . “[0-i] The sooner the better , ” said [Valeria]109-valeria . “[0-i] English skies have Puritan moods , and [we]2063-our may as well profit by [their]2066-their present jocund temper . [I]0-i never saw a bluer sky in all [Italy]11-italy . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i certainly shall not be absent from the next meeting , ” announced [Theobald]181-professor theobald , with a glance at [Hadria]211-hadria . “[0-i] Nor [I]0-i , ” said [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton . “[0-i] Such opportunities come none too often . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i , ” [Hadria]211-hadria observed , “[0-i] shall be cook - hunting . ” [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald 's jaw shut with a snap , and [he]181-professor theobald turned and left [the group]941-the group almost rudely . [HADRIA]211-hadria thought that [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald had not spoken at random , when [he]181-professor theobald said that the sweetest tribute [a woman]3753-a woman can receive is that paid to [her]3753-a woman personal charm . This unwilling admission was dragged out of [her]211-hadria by the sight of [Valeria Du Prel]109-valeria , as [the central figure of [an admiring group]5359-an admiring group]5358-the central figure of an admiring group , in [the large drawing - room at [Craddock Place]29-craddock place]5360-the large drawing - room at craddock place . [She]109-valeria was looking handsome and animated , [her]109-valeria white hair drawn proudly off [her]109-valeria brow , and placed as if with intention beside the silken curtains , whose tint of misty pale green was so becoming to [her]109-valeria beauty . [Valeria]109-valeria was holding [her]109-valeria little court , and thoroughly enjoying the admiration . “[0-i] If [we]2067-we have had to live by [our]2067-we looks for all these centuries , surely the instinct that [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald thinks [himself]181-professor theobald so penetrating to have discovered in [clever women]5346-clever women , is accounted for simply enough by heredity , ” [Hadria]211-hadria said to [herself]211-hadria , resentfully . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald was bending over [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria with an air of devotion . [Hadria]211-hadria wished that [she]109-valeria would not take [his]181-professor theobald compliments so smilingly . [Valeria]109-valeria would not be proof against [his]181-professor theobald flattery . [She]109-valeria kindled with [a child]754-a child 's frankness at praise . It stung [Hadria]211-hadria to think of [[her]211-hadria friend]4123-her friend being carelessly classed by [the Professor among women whose weakness [he]181-professor theobald understood and could play upon]5363-the professor among women whose weakness he understood and could play upon . [He]181-professor theobald would imagine that [he]181-professor theobald had discovered the mystery of the sun , because [he]181-professor theobald had observed a spot upon it , not understanding the nature of the very spot . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald looked furtively round , as if seeking some one , or watching the effect of [his]181-professor theobald conduct on [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley . Could [he]181-professor theobald be trying to make [her]109-valeria jealous of [Valeria]109-valeria ? [Hadria]211-hadria gave a sudden little laugh while [Lord Engleton]157-lord engleton — [a shy , rather taciturn man]5368-a shy , rather taciturn man — was shewing [her]5368-a shy , rather taciturn man [[his]157-lord engleton wife]573-his wife 's last picture .
