[She]211-hadria flushed , and looked hastily down [the avenue]945-the avenue . “[3089-she] [I]0-i wonder what [our]3090-our fate would be , if [anyone]806-anyone had been [there]571-there ? ” [she]211-hadria said , with a little shudder . “[806-anyone] [No one]383-no one was there , [darling]1662-darling . ” [He]181-professor theobald stood leaning over the high back of the seat , looking down at [[his]181-professor theobald companion]4118-his companion , with a smile . “[806-anyone] Do [you]1662-darling know , ” [he]181-professor theobald said , “[1662-darling] [I]0-i fear [I]0-i shall have to go up to [town]4255-town to - morrow , for the day . ” [Hadria]211-hadria 's face fell . [She]211-hadria hated [him]181-professor theobald to go away , even for a short time [she]211-hadria could not endure [her]211-hadria own thoughts when [his]181-professor theobald influence was withdrawn . [His]181-professor theobald presence wrapped [her]211-hadria in a state of dream , a false peace which [she]211-hadria courted . “[0-i] Oh no , no , ” [she]211-hadria cried , with a childish eagerness that was entirely unlike [her]211-hadria , “[0-i] do n't go . ” “[0-i] Do [you]1662-darling really care so very much ? ” [he]181-professor theobald asked , with a deep flush of pleasure . “[1662-darling] Of course [I]0-i do , of course . ” [Her]211-hadria thoughts wandered off through strange by - ways . At times , [they]6833-they would pass some black cavernous entrance to unknown labyrinths , and the frightened thoughts would hurry by . Sometimes [they]6833-they would be led decorously along [a smooth highway]6834-a smooth highway , pacing quietly ; sometimes [they]6833-they would rise to the sunlight and spread [their]6833-they wings , and then perhaps take sudden flight , like a flock of startled birds . Yes , [he]181-professor theobald needed sympathy , and faith , and love . [He]181-professor theobald had never had [anyone]806-anyone to believe in [him]181-professor theobald before . [He]181-professor theobald had met with hardness and distrust all [his]181-professor theobald life . [She]211-hadria would trust [him]181-professor theobald . [He]181-professor theobald had conquered , step by step , [his]181-professor theobald inimical conditions . [He]181-professor theobald was lonely , unused to real affection . Let [her]211-hadria try to make up for what [he]181-professor theobald had lost . Let [her]211-hadria forget [herself]211-hadria and [her]211-hadria own little woes , in the effort to fill [his]181-professor theobald life with all that [he]181-professor theobald had been forced to forego . ( An impish thought danced before [her]211-hadria for a second—“Fine[0-i] talk , but [you]3096-you know [you]3096-you love to be loved . ” ) If [her]211-hadria love were worth anything , that must be [her]211-hadria impulse . Let [her]211-hadria beware of considering [her]211-hadria own feelings , [her]211-hadria own wishes and fears . If [she]211-hadria loved , let it be fully and freely , generously and without reserve . That or nothing . ( “[3096-you] Probably it will be nothing , ” jeered [the imp]6836-the imp . ) “[3096-you] Then what , in heaven 's name , is it that [I]0-i feel ? ” [the other self]1894-the other self seemed to cry in desperation . “[0-i] An idea has struck [me]0-i , ” said [the Professor]4071-the professor , taking [her]211-hadria hand and holding it closely in [his]4071-the professor , “[0-i] Why should [you]3096-you not come up to [town]4255-town , say on Friday — don't start , dearest — it would be quite simple , and then for once in [our]3098-we lives [we]3098-we should stand , as it were , alone in [the world]334-the world , [you]3096-you and [I]0-i , without this everlasting dread of curious eyes upon [us]3098-we . Alone among [strangers]3100-strangers — what bliss ! [We]3098-we could have a day on [the river]437-the river , or [I]0-i could take [you]3096-you to see — well , anything [you]3096-you liked — [we]3098-we should be free and happy . Think of it , [Hadria]211-hadria ! to be rid of this incessant need for caution , for hypocrisy . [We]3098-we have but one life to live ; why not live it ? ” “[211-hadria] Why not live it , why not live it ? ” The words danced in [her]211-hadria head , like circles of little sprites carrying alluring wreaths of roses . “[211-hadria] Ah , [we]3098-we must be careful ; there is much at stake , ” [she]211-hadria said . [He]3096-you began to plead , eloquently and skilfully . [He]3096-you knew exactly what arguments would tell best with [her]211-hadria . [The imps]6839-the imps and [the other selves]6840-the other selves engaged in a free fight . “[211-hadria] No ; [I]0-i must not listen ; it is too dangerous . If it were not for [[my]0-i mother]4254-my mother , [I]0-i should not care for anything , but as it is , [I]0-i must risk nothing . [I]0-i have already risked too much . ” “[0-i] There would be no danger , ” [he]3096-you argued . “[0-i] Trust to [me]0-i . [I]0-i have something to lose too . It is of no use to bring the whole dead stupid weight of [the world]334-the world on [our]3098-we heads . There is no sense in lying down under a heap of rubbish , to be crushed . Let [us]3098-we go [our]3098-we way and leave [other people]3849-other people to go [theirs]3849-other people . ” “[3106-a maniac who brandished a razor in one] Easier said than done . ” “[3106-a maniac who brandished a razor in one] Oh no ; [the world]334-the world must be treated as one would treat [a maniac who brandished a razor in one]3106-a maniac who brandished a razor in one 's face . Direct defiance argues folly worse than [his]3106-a maniac who brandished a razor in one . ” “[3106-a maniac who brandished a razor in one] Of course , but all this subterfuge and deceit is hateful . ” “[329-one] Not if [one]329-one considers the facts of the case . [The maniac - world]3108-the maniac - world insists upon uniformity and obedience , especially in that department of life where uniformity is impossible . [You]3109-you do n't suppose that it is ever really attained by [any human being who deserves the name]3110-any human being who deserves the name ? Never ! [We]3098-we all wear the livery of [[our]3098-we master]3111-our master and live [our]3098-we own lives not the less . ” “[3113-it] Ah , [I]0-i doubt that , ” said [Hadria]211-hadria . “[3113-it] [I]0-i think the livery affects [us]3098-we all , right through to the bones and marrow . [What young clergyman]3112-what young clergyman was [it]3113-it who told [me]0-i that as soon as [he]3112-what young clergyman put on [his]3112-what young clergyman canonicals , [he]3112-what young clergyman felt [a different man , mind , heart , and personality]3114-a different man , mind , heart , and personality ? ” “[3112-what young clergyman] Well , [your]0-i livery has never made [you]0-i , [Hadria]211-hadria , and that is all [I]0-i care for . ” “[211-hadria] Indeed , [I]0-i am not so sure . ” “[211-hadria] [It]3115-it has not turned [you]0-i out a [Mrs. Jordan]179-mrs. jordan or [a Mrs. Walker]3116-a mrs. walker , for instance . ” “[3116-a mrs. walker] To the great regret of [[my]0-i well - wishers]3117-my well - wishers . ” “[3116-a mrs. walker] To the great regret of [[your]0-i inferiors]3118-your inferiors . There is nothing that [people]3687-people regret so bitterly as superiority to [themselves]3687-people . ” [Hadria]211-hadria laughed . “[0-i] [I]0-i am always afraid of the gratifying argument based on the assumption of superiority ; [one]329-one is apt to be brought down a peg , if ever one indulges in it . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i ca n't see that much vanity is implied in claiming superiority to [the common idiot of commerce]3121-the common idiot of commerce , ” said [the Professor]4071-the professor , with a shrug . “[3122-he] [He]3122-he is in [the family]360-the family , ” [Hadria]211-hadria reminded [him]4071-the professor . “[360-the family] [The human family]3124-the human family ; yes , confound [him]3122-he ! ” [They]6842-they laughed , and [the Professor]4071-the professor , after a pause , continued [his]4071-the professor pleading . “[211-hadria] It only needs a little courage , [Hadria]211-hadria . [[My]0-i love]3125-my love , [[my]0-i dear one]3126-my dear one , do n't shake [your]211-hadria head . ” [He]4071-the professor came forward and sat down on the seat beside [her]211-hadria , bending towards [her]211-hadria persuasively . “[211-hadria] Promise [me]0-i to come to [town]4255-town on Friday , [Hadria]211-hadria — promise [me]0-i , [dearest]3128-dearest . ” “[0-i] But if — oh , how [I]0-i hate all the duplicity that this involves ! It creates wretched situations , whichever way one turns . [I]0-i never realized into what a labyrinth it would lead [one]329-one . [I]0-i should like to speak out and be honest about it . ” “[832-your mother] And [[your]0-i mother]832-your mother ? ” “[832-your mother] Oh , [I]0-i know of course — ” [Hadria]211-hadria set [her]211-hadria teeth . “[832-your mother] It drives [me]0-i mad , all this ! ” “[211-hadria] Oh , [Hadria]211-hadria ! And [you]0-i do n't count [me]0-i then ? ” “[0-i] Obviously [I]0-i count [you]0-i . But [one]329-one 's whole life becomes a lie . ” “[329-one] That is surely [schoolgirl]3132-schoolgirl 's reasoning . Strange that [you]0-i should be guilty of it ! Is [one]329-one 's life a lie because [one]329-one makes so bold as to keep [one]329-one 's own counsel ? Must [one]329-one take [the world]334-the world into [one]329-one 's confidence , or stand condemned as [a liar]3139-a liar ? Oh , [Hadria]211-hadria , this is childish ! ” “[211-hadria] Yes , [I]0-i am getting weak - minded , [I]0-i know , ” [she]0-i said feverishly . “[0-i] [I]0-i resent being forced to resort to this sort of thing when [I]0-i am doing nothing wrong , according to [my]0-i own belief . Why should [I]0-i be forced to behave as if [I]0-i were sinning against [my]0-i conscience ? ” “[0-i] So [you]0-i may say ; that is [your]0-i grievance , not [your]0-i fault . But , after all , compromise is necessary in everything , and the best way is to make the compromise lightly and with a shrug of the shoulders , and then [you]0-i find that life becomes fairly manageable and often extremely pleasant . ” “[0-i] Yes , [I]0-i suppose [you]0-i are right . ” [Hadria]211-hadria was picking the petals off a buttercup one by one , and when [she]211-hadria had destroyed one golden corolla , [she]211-hadria attacked another . “[0-i] Fate is ironical ! ” [she]211-hadria exclaimed . “[0-i] Never in [my]0-i life did [I]0-i feel more essentially frank and open - hearted than [I]0-i feel now . ” [The Professor]4071-the professor laughed . “[0-i] [My]0-i impulse is to indulge in that sort of bluff , boisterous honesty which forms so charming a feature of [our]3140-our national character . Is it not disastrous ? ” “[162-mrs. walker] It is a little inopportune , ” [Theobald]181-professor theobald admitted with a chuckle . “[162-mrs. walker] Oh , it is no laughing matter ! It amounts to a monomania . [I]0-i long to take [Mrs. Walker]162-mrs. walker aside and say ‘ Hi ! look here , [Mrs. Walker]162-mrs. walker , [I]0-i just want to mention to [you]162-mrs. walker — ’ and so on ; and [Mrs. Jordan]179-mrs. jordan inspires [me]0-i with a still more fatal impulse of frankness . If only for the fun of the thing , [I]0-i long to do it . ” “[179-mrs. jordan] [You]0-i are quite mad , [Hadria]211-hadria ! ” exclaimed [the Professor]4071-the professor , laughing . “[211-hadria] Oh ; no , ” [she]0-i said , “[211-hadria] only bewildered . [I]0-i want desperately to be bluff and outspoken , but [I]0-i suppose [I]0-i must dissemble . [I]0-i long painfully to be like ‘ [truthful James]279-truthful james , ’ but [I]0-i must follow in the footsteps of [the sneaky little boy who came to a bad end because [he]3141-the sneaky little boy who came to a bad end because he told a lie told a lie]3141-the sneaky little boy who came to a bad end because he told a lie . The question is : Shall [[my]0-i mother]4254-my mother be sacrificed to this passionate love of truth ? ” “[0-i] Or shall [I]0-i ? ” asked [the Professor]4071-the professor . “[0-i] [You]0-i seem to forget [me]0-i . [You]0-i frighten [me]0-i , [Hadria]211-hadria . To indulge in frankness just now , means to throw [me]0-i over , and if [you]0-i did that , [I]0-i do n't know how [I]0-i should be able to stand it . [I]0-i should cut [my]0-i throat . ” [Hadria]211-hadria buried [her]211-hadria face in [her]211-hadria hands , as if to shut out distracting sights and sounds , so that [she]211-hadria might think more clearly . It seemed , at that moment , as if cutting one 's throat would be the only way out of the growing difficulty . How could it go on ? And yet , how could [she]211-hadria give [him]6847-him up ? ( [The imp]6836-the imp gave a fiendish chuckle . ) It would be so unfair , so cruel , and what would life be without [him]6847-him ? ( “[0-i] Moral development impossible ! ” cried [the imp]6836-the imp , with a yell of laughter . ) It would be so mean to go back now—(“Shocking[0-i] ! ” exclaimed [the imp]6836-the imp . ) Assuming that [she]211-hadria ought never to have allowed this thing to happen ( “[0-i] Oh , fie ! ” ) because [she]211-hadria bore [another man]6851-another man 's name ( not being permitted to retain [her]211-hadria own ) , ought [she]211-hadria to throw [this man]4247-this man over , on second and ( per assumption ) better thoughts , or did the false step oblige [her]211-hadria to continue in the path [she]211-hadria had entered ? “[0-i] [I]0-i seem to have got [myself]0-i into one of those situations where there is no right , ” [she]0-i exclaimed . “[3143-you] [You]3143-you forget [your]3143-you own words : [A woman in relation to society]3144-a woman in relation to society is in the position of [a captive]3145-a captive ; [she]3144-a woman in relation to society may justly evade the prison rules , if [she]3144-a woman in relation to society can . ” “[3144-a woman in relation to society] So [she]3144-a woman in relation to society may ; only [I]0-i want so desperately to wrench away the bars instead of evading the rules . ” “[0-i] Try to remember that [you]0-i — ” [The Professor]4071-the professor stopped abruptly and stood listening . [They]6854-they looked at [one another]3945-one another . [Hadria]211-hadria was deadly white . A step was advancing along the winding path through the bushes behind [them]6854-they : a half over - grown path , that led from a small door in the wall that ran round [the park]2144-the park . It was [the nearest route from [the station]3893-the station to [the house]296-the house]6857-the nearest route from the station to the house , and a short cut could be taken this way through [the garden]3867-the garden , to [Craddock Place]29-craddock place . “[0-i] It 's all right , ” [the Professor]4071-the professor said in a low voice ; “[3146-we] [we]3146-we were saying nothing compromising . ” The step drew nearer . “[3146-we] [Some visitor to [Craddock Place]29-craddock place probably , who has come down by the 4.20 from [town]4255-town]3147-some visitor to craddock place probably , who has come down by the 4.20 from town . ” “[3147-some visitor to craddock place probably , who has come down by the 4.20 from town] [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue ! ” [Hadria]211-hadria had sprung up , and was standing , with flushed cheeks , beside [[her]211-hadria calmer companion]6862-her calmer companion . [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue 's voice broke the momentary silence . [He]116-professor fortescue gave a warm smile of pleasure and came forward with out - stretched hand . “[116-professor fortescue] The hoped - for instant has come sooner than [I]0-i thought , ” [he]116-professor fortescue cried genially . [Hadria]211-hadria was shocked to see [him]116-professor fortescue looking very ill . [He]116-professor fortescue said that [[his]116-professor fortescue doctor]6863-his doctor had bullied [him]116-professor fortescue , at last , into deciding to go [south]6864-south . [His]116-professor fortescue arrangements for departure had been rather hastily made , and [he]116-professor fortescue had telegraphed this morning , to [Craddock Place]29-craddock place , to announce [his]116-professor fortescue coming . [[His]116-professor fortescue luggage]6865-his luggage was following in [a hand - cart]6866-a hand - cart , and [he]116-professor fortescue was taking the short cut through [the Priory gardens]5796-the priory gardens . [He]116-professor fortescue had come to say good - bye to [[them]6868-them all]6869-them all . [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria , [he]116-professor fortescue added , had already made up [her]109-valeria mind to go abroad , and [he]116-professor fortescue hoped to come across [her]109-valeria somewhere in [Italy]11-italy . [She]109-valeria had given [him]116-professor fortescue all news . [He]116-professor fortescue looked anxiously at [Hadria]211-hadria . The flush had left [her]211-hadria face now , and the altered lines were but too obvious . “[0-i] [You]3149-you ought to have change too , ” [he]116-professor fortescue said , “[3149-you] [you]3149-you are not looking well . ” [She]211-hadria laughed nervously . “[3149-you] Oh , [I]0-i am all right . ” “[0-i] Let 's sit down a moment , if [you]3149-you were not discussing anything very important — ” “[3150-we] Indeed , [we]3150-we were , [[my]0-i dear]3722-my dear [Fortescue]116-professor fortescue , ” said [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald , drawing [[his]181-professor theobald colleague]1971-his colleague on to the seat , “[3150-we] and [your]3149-you clear head would throw much light on the philosophy of the question . ” “[3149-you] Oh , a question of abstract philosophy , ” said [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue . “[3149-you] Are [you]3149-you disagreeing ? ” “[3149-you] Not exactly . The question that turned up , in the course of discussion , was this : If [a man]3704-a man stands in a position which is itself the result of an aggression upon [his]3704-a man liberty and [his]3704-a man human rights , is [he]3704-a man in honour bound to abide by the laws which are laid down to coerce [him]3704-a man ? ” “[3704-a man] Obviously not , ” replied [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue . “[3704-a man] Is [he]3704-a man morally justified in using every means [he]3704-a man can lay hold of to overcome the peculiar difficulties under which [he]3704-a man has been tyrannously placed ? ” “[3704-a man] Not merely justified , but [I]0-i should say [he]3704-a man was [a poor fool]3153-a poor fool if [he]3704-a man refrained from doing so . ” “[3153-a poor fool] That is exactly what [I]0-i say . ” “[0-i] Surely [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley does not demur ? ” “[154-mrs. temperley] No ; [I]0-i quite agree as to the right . [I]0-i only say that the means which the situation may make necessary are sometimes very hateful . ” “[0-i] Ah , that is among the cruelest of [the victim]870-the victim 's wrongs , ” said [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue . “[3704-a man] [He]3704-a man is reduced to employ artifices that [he]3704-a man would despise , were [he]3704-a man [a free agent]3155-a free agent . Take a crude instance : [a man]3704-a man is overpowered by [a band of [brigands]3158-brigands]3157-a band of brigands . Surely [he]3704-a man is justified in deceiving [those gentlemen of [the road]4037-the road]3159-those gentlemen of the road , and in telling and acting lies without scruple . ” “[3704-a man] The parallel is exact , ” said [Theobald]181-professor theobald , with a triumphant glance at [Hadria]211-hadria . “[3704-a man] [Honour]280-honour departs where force comes in . [No man]4555-no man is bound in honour to [[his]4555-no man captor]3162-his captor , though [[his]4555-no man captor]3162-his captor will naturally try to persuade [[his]3162-his captor prisoner]3164-his prisoner to regard [himself]3162-his captor as so bound . And few would be [our]3165-our oppressions , if that persuasion did not generally succeed ! ” “[606-women] The relations of [women]606-women to [society]367-society for instance — ” began [Theobald]181-professor theobald . “[606-women] Ah , exactly . The success of that device may be said to constitute the history of womanhood . Take [[my]0-i brigand]3168-my brigand instance and write it large , and [you]3169-you have the whole case in a nutshell . ” “[3169-you] Then [you]3169-you would recommend rank rebellion , either by force or artifice , according as circumstances might require ? ” asked [Hadria]211-hadria . [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue looked round at [her]211-hadria , half anxiously , half enquiringly . “[3169-you] There are perils , remember , ” [he]116-professor fortescue warned . “[3169-you] [The woman]4547-the woman is , by [our]3165-our assumption , [[the brigand]3171-the brigand 's captive]3172-the brigand 's captive . If [she]4547-the woman offends [[her]4547-the woman brigand]3173-her brigand , [he]3173-her brigand has hideous punishments to inflict . [He]3173-her brigand can subject [her]4547-the woman to pain and indignity at [his]3173-her brigand good pleasure . Torture and mutilation , metaphorically speaking , are possible to [him]3173-her brigand . How could one deliberately counsel [her]4547-the woman to risk all that ? ” There was a long silence . [Hadria]211-hadria had been growing more and more restless since the arrival of [the new - comer]1028-the new - comer . [She]211-hadria took no further part in the conversation . [She]211-hadria was struggling to avoid making comparisons between [[her]211-hadria two companions]6872-her two companions . The contrast was startling . Every cadence of [their]3175-they voices , every gesture , proclaimed the radical difference of nature and calibre . [Hadria]211-hadria rose abruptly . [She]211-hadria looked pale and perturbed . “[3174-you] Do n't [you]3174-you think [we]3175-they have sat [here]3762-here long enough ? ” [she]211-hadria asked . [They]3175-they both looked a little surprised , but [they]3175-they acquiesced at once . [The three]6873-the three walked together down [the yew avenue]2414-the yew avenue , and out across [the lawn]1843-the lawn . [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue recalled [their]3175-they past meetings among [these serene retreats]6876-these serene retreats , and wished [they]3175-they could come over again . “[3174-you] Nothing ever does come over again , ” said [Hadria]211-hadria . [Theobald]181-professor theobald glanced at [her]211-hadria , meaningly . “[3174-you] Look here , [[my]0-i dear fellow]3821-my dear fellow , ” [he]181-professor theobald said , grasping [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue by the arm , and bending confidentially towards [him]116-professor fortescue , “[0-i] [I]0-i should like those meetings to repeat [themselves]3178-themselves ad infinitum . [I]0-i have made up [my]0-i mind at last . [I]0-i want to take [the Priory]1664-the priory . ” [Hadria]211-hadria turned deadly pale , and stumbled slightly . “[0-i] Well , take it by all means . [I]0-i should be only too glad to let it to [a tenant who would look after [the old place]3181-the old place]3180-a tenant who would look after the old place . ” “[3182-we] [We]3182-we must talk it over , ” said [Theobald]181-professor theobald . “[3182-we] That wo n't take long , [I]0-i fancy . [We]3182-we talked it over once before , [you]3821-my dear fellow remember , and then [you]3821-my dear fellow suddenly changed [your]3821-my dear fellow mind . ” “[3821-my dear fellow] Yes ; but [my]0-i mind is steady now . [The Priory]1664-the priory is [the place of all others that [I]0-i should like to pass [my]0-i days in]3184-the place of all others that i should like to pass my days in . ” “[0-i] Well , [I]0-i think [you]3821-my dear fellow are wise , [Theobald]181-professor theobald . [The place]981-the place has great charm , and [you]3821-my dear fellow have [friends]886-friends [here]3762-here . ” “[886-friends] Yes , indeed ! ” exclaimed [Theobald]181-professor theobald . [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue looked vaguely round , as if expecting [Hadria]211-hadria to express some neighbourly sentiment , but [she]211-hadria said nothing . [He]181-professor theobald noticed how very ill [she]211-hadria was looking . “[886-friends] Are [you]3821-my dear fellow feeling the heat too severe ? ” [he]181-professor theobald asked in concern . “[3821-my dear fellow] Shall [we]3188-we take a rest under these trees ? ” But [Hadria]211-hadria preferred to go on and rest at [home]3770-home . [She]211-hadria asked when [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue was coming to see [them]3188-we at [the Red House]34-the red house , but [her]211-hadria tone was less open and warm than usual , in addressing [him]181-professor theobald . [He]181-professor theobald said that to - morrow [he]181-professor theobald would walk over in the afternoon , if [he]181-professor theobald might . [Hadria]211-hadria would not allow [[her]211-hadria companions]5823-her companions to come out of [their]5823-her companions way to accompany [[her]211-hadria [home]3770-home]3897-her home . At the Priory gate — where [the griffins]5335-the griffins were grinning as derisively as ever at the ridiculous ways of [men]3698-men — [they]3188-we took [[their]3188-we respective roads]6883-their respective roads . Some domestic catastrophe had happened at [the Red House]4718-the red house . [The cook]1504-the cook had called [Mary]128-mary “[3821-my dear fellow] names , ” and [Mary]128-mary declared [she]128-mary must leave . [Hadria]211-hadria shrugged [her]211-hadria shoulders . “[3821-my dear fellow] Oh , well then , [I]0-i suppose [you]3189-you must , ” [she]211-hadria said wearily , and retired to [[her]211-hadria room]4419-her room , in a mood to be cynically amused at the tragedies that [the human being]5264-the human being manufactures for [himself]5264-the human being , lest [he]5264-the human being should not find the tragedies of birth and death and parting , and the solitude of the spirit , sufficient to occupy [him]5264-the human being during [his]5264-the human being little pilgrimage . [She]211-hadria sat by the open window that looked out over [the familiar fields]6888-the familiar fields , and [the garden that was gay with summer flowers]6889-the garden that was gay with summer flowers . The red roof of [the Priory]1664-the priory could just be caught through the trees of [the park]2144-the park . [She]211-hadria wished the little pilgrimage were over . A common enough wish , [she]211-hadria commented , but surely not unreasonable . The picture of [those two men]6892-those two men came back to [her]211-hadria , in spite of every effort to banish it . [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue had affected [her]211-hadria as if [he]116-professor fortescue had brought with [him]116-professor fortescue a new atmosphere , and disastrous was the result . It seemed as if [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald had suddenly become a stranger to [her]211-hadria , whom [she]211-hadria criticised , whose commonness of fibre , ah [me]3189-you ! whose coarseness , [she]211-hadria saw as [she]211-hadria might have seen it in some casual acquaintance . And yet [she]211-hadria had loved [this man]4247-this man , [she]211-hadria had allowed [him]4247-this man to passionately profess love for [her]211-hadria . [His]4247-this man companionship , in the deepest sense , had been chosen by [her]211-hadria for life . To sit by and listen to that conversation , feeling every moment how utterly [he]4247-this man and [she]211-hadria were , after all , [strangers to one another]6894-strangers to one another , how completely unbroken was the solitude that [she]211-hadria had craved to dispel — that had been horrible . What had lain at the root of [her]211-hadria conduct ? How had [she]211-hadria deceived [herself]211-hadria ? Was it not for the sake of mere excitement , distraction ? Was it not the sensuous side of [her]211-hadria nature that had been touched , while the rest had been posing in the foreground ? But no , that was only partly true . There had been more in it than that ; very much more , or [she]211-hadria could not have deceived [herself]211-hadria so completely . It was this craving to fill the place of [her]211-hadria lost art,—but oh , what morbid nonsense it had all been ! Why , for the first time in [her]211-hadria life , did [she]211-hadria feel ashamed to meet [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue ? Obviously , it was not because [she]211-hadria thought [he]4247-this man would disapprove of [her]211-hadria breaking the social law . It was because [she]211-hadria had fallen below [her]211-hadria own standard , because [she]211-hadria had been hypocritical with [herself]211-hadria , played [herself]211-hadria false , and acted contemptibly , hatefully ! [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue 's mere presence had hunted out the truth from its hiding - place . [He]116-professor fortescue had made further self - sophistication impossible . [She]211-hadria buried [her]211-hadria face in [her]211-hadria hands , in an agony of shame . [She]211-hadria had known all along , that this had not been a profound and whole - hearted sentiment . [She]211-hadria had known all along , of what a poor feverish nature it was ; yet [she]211-hadria had chosen to persuade [herself]211-hadria that it was all , or nearly all , that [she]211-hadria had dreamed of a perfect human relationship . [She]211-hadria had tried to arrange facts in such a light as to simulate that idea . It was so paltry , so contemptible . Why could [she]211-hadria not at least have been honest with [herself]211-hadria , and owned to the nature of the infatuation ? That , at any rate , would have been straightforward . [Her]211-hadria self - scorn made the colour surge into [her]211-hadria cheeks and burn painfully over neck and brow . “[3189-you] How [little one]2165-little one knows [oneself]3191-oneself . Here am [I]0-i , who rebel against the beliefs of [others]432-others , sinning against [my]0-i own . Here am [I]0-i , who turn up [my]0-i nose at the popular gods , deriding [my]0-i own private and particular gods in [[their]3193-their very temples]3194-their very temples ! That [I]0-i have done , and heaven alone knows where [I]0-i should have stopped in the wild work , if this had not happened . [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue has no need to speak . [His]116-professor fortescue gentleness , [his]116-professor fortescue charity , are as rods to scourge [one]329-one ! ” WHEN [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue called at [the Red House]4718-the red house , [he]116-professor fortescue found that the blinds , in [the drawing - room]737-the drawing - room , were all half down . [Hadria]211-hadria held the conversation to the subject of [his]116-professor fortescue plans . [He]116-professor fortescue knew [her]211-hadria well enough to read the meaning of that quiet tone , with a subtle cadence in it , just at the end of a phrase , that went to [his]116-professor fortescue heart . To [him]116-professor fortescue it testified to an unspeakable regret . It was difficult to define the change in [her]211-hadria manner , but it conveyed to [the visitor]4013-the visitor the impression that [she]211-hadria had lost belief in [herself]211-hadria , or in some one ; that [she]211-hadria had received a severe shock , and knew no longer what to trust or how to steer . [She]211-hadria seemed to speak across some vast spiritual distance , an effect not produced by reserve or coldness , but by a wistful , acquiescent , subdued quality , expressive of uncertainty , of disorder in [her]211-hadria conceptions of things . “[116-professor fortescue] How tempting those two easy - chairs look , under the old tree on [[your]3196-you lawn]3197-your lawn , ” said [the Professor]4071-the professor . “[116-professor fortescue] Would n't it be pleasant to go out ? ” [Hadria]211-hadria hesitated for a second , and then rose . “[116-professor fortescue] Certainly ; [we]3198-their will have tea [there]571-there . ” When [they]3198-their were seated under the shade taking [their]3198-their tea , with the canopy of walnut leaves above [their]3198-their heads , [the Professor]4071-the professor saw that [Hadria]211-hadria shewed signs of serious trouble . The haggard lines , the marks of suffering , were not to be hidden in the clear light of the summer afternoon . [He]4071-the professor insensibly shifted [his]4071-the professor chair so as not to have to gaze at [her]211-hadria when [he]4071-the professor spoke . That seemed to be a relief to [her]211-hadria . “[116-professor fortescue] [Valeria]109-valeria is here till the day after to - morrow , ” [she]211-hadria said . “[109-valeria] [She]109-valeria has gone for a walk , and has probably forgotten the tea - hour ; but [I]0-i hope [you]3196-you will see [her]109-valeria . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i want to find out what [her]109-valeria plans are . It would be pleasant to come across [one another]3945-one another abroad . [I]0-i wish [you]3196-you were coming too . ” “[0-i] Ah , so do [I.]0-i ” “[0-i] [I]0-i suppose it 's impossible . ” “[0-i] Absolutely . ” “[0-i] For the mind , there is no tonic like travel , ” [he]3196-you said . “[0-i] It must be a sovereign cure for egoism . ” “[0-i] If anything will cure that disease . ” [Her]0-i face saddened . “[3196-you] [You]3196-you believe it is quite incurable ? ” “[3196-you] If it is constitutional . ” “[3196-you] Do n't [you]3196-you think that sometimes [people]3687-people grow egoistic through having to fight incessantly for existence — [I]0-i mean for individual existence ? ” “[0-i] It certainly is the instinct of moral self - preservation . It corresponds to the raised arm when a blow threatens . ” “[3196-you] One has the choice between egoism and extinction . ” “[3196-you] It almost amounts to that . Perhaps , after long experience and much sufferings the individuality may become secure , and the armour no longer necessary , but this is a bitter process . [Most people]4077-most people become extinct , and then congratulate [themselves]4077-most people on self - conquest . ” “[4077-most people] Yes , [I]0-i suppose so , ” said [Hadria]211-hadria musingly . “[4077-most people] How dangerous it is to congratulate [oneself]3203-oneself on anything ! [One]329-one never is so near to folly as then . ” [The Professor]4071-the professor threw some crumbs to a chaffinch , which had flown down within a few yards of the tea - table . “[329-one] [I]0-i think [you]3196-you are disposed , at present , to criticise [yourself]3196-you too mercilessly , ” [he]4071-the professor said in a tone that had drawn forth many a confidence . It was not to be resisted . “[3196-you] No ; that would be difficult . ” “[3196-you] [Your]3196-you conscience may accuse [you]3196-you severely , but who of [us]3205-us escapes such accusations ? Be a little charitable with [yourself]3196-you , as [you]3196-you would with [others]432-others . Life , [you]3196-you know , is not such an easy game to play . [Beginners]3207-beginners must make wrong moves now and then . ” There was a long pause . “[0-i] It sounds so mild when [you]0-i put it like that . But [I]0-i am not [a beginner]3208-a beginner . [I]0-i am quite [a veteran]3209-a veteran , yet [I]0-i am not seasoned . [My]0-i impulses are more imperious , more blinding than [I]0-i had the least idea of . ” ( The words hastened on . ) “[0-i] Life comes and pulls [one]329-one by the sleeve ; stirs , prompts , bewilders , tempts in a thousand ways ; emotion rises in whirlwinds — and [one]329-one is confused , and reels and gropes and stumbles , and then some cruel , clear day one awakes to find the print of intoxicated footsteps in [the precincts of [the sanctuary]3213-the sanctuary]3212-the precincts of the sanctuary , and recognises [oneself]329-one as [desecrator]3214-desecrator . ” [The Professor]4071-the professor leant forward in [his]4071-the professor low chair . [The chaffinch]6902-the chaffinch gave a light chirp , as if to recall [him]4071-the professor to [his]4071-the professor duty . [Hadria]211-hadria performed it for [him]4071-the professor . [The chaffinch]6902-the chaffinch flew off with the booty . “[3214-desecrator] There is no suffering so horrible as that which involves remorse or self - contempt , ” [he]4071-the professor said , and [his]4071-the professor voice trembled . “[3214-desecrator] To have to settle down to look upon some part of [one]329-one 's action , of [one]329-one 's moral self , with shame or scorn , is almost intolerable . ” “[3214-desecrator] Quite intolerable ! ” “[3214-desecrator] [We]3217-they will not extend to [ourselves]3217-they the forbearance due to erring humanity . This puts [us]3217-they too much on a level with the rest — is that not often the reason of [our]3217-they harsh self - judgments ? ” “[3214-desecrator] Oh , [I]0-i have no doubt there is something mean and conceited at the bottom of it ! ” exclaimed [Hadria]211-hadria . There was a step on the lawn behind [them]3217-they . [The Professor]4071-the professor sprang up . [He]4071-the professor went to meet [Valeria]109-valeria and [they]3217-they came to the table together , talking . [Valeria]109-valeria 's eyes were bright and [her]109-valeria manner animated . Yes , [she]109-valeria was going abroad . It would be delightful to meet somewhere , if chance favoured [them]3217-they . [She]109-valeria thought of [Italy]11-italy . And at that magic name , [they]3217-they fell into reminiscences of former journeyings ; [they]3217-they talked of [towns]6905-towns and [temples]6906-temples and [palaces]6907-palaces , of art , of sunshine ; and [Hadria]211-hadria listened silently . Once , in [her]109-valeria girlhood , when [she]109-valeria was scarcely sixteen [she]109-valeria had gone with [[her]109-valeria parents]3931-her parents and [Algitha]81-algitha for a tour in [Italy]11-italy . It was a short but vivid experience which had tinged [her]109-valeria life , leaving a memory and a longing that never died . The movement of travel , the sense of change and richness offered to eye and mind , remained with [her]109-valeria always ; the vision of a strange , tumultuous , beautiful world ; of [exquisite Italian cities , of [forests and seas]6910-forests and seas]6909-exquisite italian cities , of forests and seas ; of [classic plains]6911-classic plains and [snow - capped mountains]6912-snow - capped mountains ; of treasures of art — the eternal evidence of [man]332-man 's aloofness , on one side of [him]332-man , from the savage element in nature — and glimpses of cathedral domes and [palace walls]6914-palace walls ; and [villages]5951-villages clinging like living things to [the hill - sides]6916-the hill - sides , or dreaming away [their]5951-villages drowsy days in [some sunny valley]6917-some sunny valley . And then the mystery that every work of [man]332-man enshrines ; the life , the thought , the need that it embodies , and the passionate histories that it hides ! It was as if the sum and circumstance of life had mirrored itself in the memory , once and for all . [The South]10-the south lured [her]0-i with its languor , its colour , its hot sun , and its splendid memories . It was exquisite pleasure and exquisite pain to listen to the anticipations of [these two , who were able to wander]6919-these two , who were able to wander as [they]6919-these two , who were able to wander would . “[281-siena] [Siena]281-siena ? ” said [Valeria]109-valeria with a sigh , “[281-siena] [I]0-i used to know [Siena]281-siena when [I]0-i was young and happy . That was where [I]0-i made the fatal mistake in [my]0-i life . It is all a thing of the past now . [I]0-i might have married [a good and brilliantly intellectual man]3218-a good and brilliantly intellectual man , whom [I]0-i could respect and warmly admire ; for whom [I]0-i had every feeling but the one that [we]3219-we romantic women think so essential , and that [people]3687-people assure [us]3219-we is the first to depart . ” “[0-i] [You]0-i regret that [you]0-i held fast to [your]0-i own standard ? ” said [Hadria]211-hadria . “[0-i] [I]0-i regret that [I]0-i could not see the wisdom of taking the good that was offered to [me]0-i , since [I]0-i could not have that which [I]0-i wished . Now [I]0-i have neither . ” “[0-i] How do [you]0-i know [you]0-i would have found the other good really satisfactory ! ” “[0-i] [I]0-i believe in the normal , ” said [Valeria]109-valeria , “[0-i] having devoted [my]0-i existence to an experiment of the abnormal . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i do n't think what [we]3219-we call the normal is , by any means , so safe as it sounds , for [civilized women]3221-civilized women at any rate , ” observed [the Professor]4071-the professor . [Valeria]109-valeria shook [her]109-valeria head , and remained silent . But [her]0-i face expressed the sad thoughts left unsaid . In youth , it was all very well . One had [the whole world]6921-the whole world before one , life to explore , [one]329-one 's powers to test . But later on , when all that seemed to promise fades away , when the dreams drift out of sight , and strenuous efforts repeated and repeated , are beaten down by the eternal obstacles ; when the heart is wearied by delay , disappointment , infruition , vain toil , then [this once intoxicating world]6923-this once intoxicating world becomes a place of desolation to [the woman who has rebelled against the common lot]6924-the woman who has rebelled against the common lot . And all the old instincts awake , to haunt and torment ; to demand that which reason has learnt to deny or to scorn ; to burden [[their]3221-civilized women victims]6925-their victims with the cruel heritage of the past ; to whisper regrets and longings , and sometimes to stir to a conflict and desperation that end in madness . “[0-i] [I]0-i believe [I]0-i should have been happier , if [I]0-i had married [some commonplace worthy in early life]3222-some commonplace worthy in early life , and been [the mother of ten children]3223-the mother of ten children , ” [Valeria]109-valeria observed , aloud . [Hadria]211-hadria laughed . “[0-i] By this time , [you]0-i or [the ten children]3224-the ten children would have come to some tragic end . [I]0-i do n't know which [I]0-i would pity most . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i do n't see why [I]0-i should n't be able to do what [other women]4882-other women have done , ” cried [Valeria]109-valeria . “[0-i] A good deal more . But think , [Valeria]109-valeria , of ten particular constitutions to grapple with , ten sets of garments to provide , ten series of ailments to combat , ten — no , let [me]0-i see , two hundred and forty teeth to take to the dentist , not to mention [characters]3226-characters and consciences in all [their]3226-characters developments and phases , rising , on this appalling decimal system of [yours]0-i , to regions of arithmetic far beyond [my]0-i range . ” “[109-valeria] [You]109-valeria exaggerate preposterously ! ” cried [Valeria]109-valeria , half annoyed , although [she]109-valeria laughed . [She]109-valeria had the instinctive human desire to assert [her]109-valeria ability in the direction where of all others it was lacking . “[109-valeria] And think of the uprush of impulse , good and evil ; the stirring of the thought , the movements of longing and wonder , and then all the greedy selfishness of youth , with its untamed vigours and its superb hopes . What help does [a child]754-a child get from [[its]754-a child parents]3228-its parents , in the midst of this tumult , out of which silently , [the future man]3229-the future man or [woman]3844-woman emerges — and grows , remember , according to the manner in which [the world]334-the world meets these generous or these baser movements of the soul ? ” “[109-valeria] [You]109-valeria would frighten [anyone]806-anyone from parenthood ! ” cried [Valeria]109-valeria , discontentedly . “[109-valeria] Admit at least , that eight , or even seven , would have satisfied [you]109-valeria . ” “[109-valeria] Well , [I]0-i do n't mind foregoing the last three or four , ” said [Valeria]109-valeria . “[0-i] But seriously , [I]0-i think that [a home]511-a home and so forth , is the best that life has to offer to [[us]3234-us women]3235-us women . It is , perhaps , not asking much , but [I]0-i believe if one goes further , one fares worse . ” “[3234-us] [We]3234-us all think the toothache would be so much more bearable , if it were only in the other tooth , ” said [the Professor]4071-the professor . A silence fell upon [the three]6873-the three . [Their]6873-the three thoughts were evidently busy . “[0-i] [I]0-i feel sorry , ” [the Professor]4071-the professor said at last , “[0-i] that this should be [your]3236-your testimony . It has always seemed to [me]0-i ridiculous that [a woman]3753-a woman could not gratify [her]3753-a woman domestic sentiments , without being claimed by [them]3238-them , body and soul . But [I]0-i hoped that [[our]3234-us more developed women]3239-our more developed women would show [us]3234-us that [they]3239-our more developed women could make a full and useful and interesting life for [themselves]3239-our more developed women , even if that particular side of existence were denied [them]3239-our more developed women . [I]0-i thought [they]3239-our more developed women might forego it for the sake of other things . ” “[0-i] Not without regretting it . ” “[0-i] Yet [I]0-i have met [women who held different opinions]3240-women who held different opinions . ” “[3241-inexperienced women] Probably rather [inexperienced women]3241-inexperienced women , ” said [Valeria]109-valeria . “[1477-young women] [Young women]1477-young women , but — ” “[1477-young women] Ah , [young women]1477-young women . What do [they]1477-young women know ? The element of real horror in [a woman]3753-a woman 's life does not betray [itself]3245-itself , until the moment when the sense of age approaches . Then , and not till then , [she]3753-a woman knows how much mere superficial and transitory attractions have had to do with making [her]3753-a woman life liveable and interesting . Then , and not till then , [she]3753-a woman realizes that [she]3753-a woman has unconsciously held the position of adventuress in [society]367-society , getting what [she]3753-a woman could out of it , by means of personal charm ; never resting on established right , for [she]3753-a woman has none . As [a wife]1373-a wife , [she]3753-a woman acquires a sort of reflected right . [One]329-one must respect [her]3753-a woman over whom Mr. So - and - So has rights of property . Well , is it not wise to take what [one]329-one can get — the little glory of being the property of [Mr. So - and - So]3249-mr. so - and - so ? [I]0-i have scorned this opportunism all [my]0-i life , and now [I]0-i regret having scorned it . And [I]0-i think , if [you]3250-you could get [women]606-women to be sincere , [they]606-women would tell [you]3250-you the same tale . ” “[606-women] And what do [you]3250-you think of the scheme of life , which almost forces upon [[our]3252-we finest women]3253-our finest women , or tempts [them]3253-our finest women to practise , this sort of opportunism ? ” “[3250-you] [I]0-i think it is simply savage , ” answered [Valeria]109-valeria . Again a silence fell on [the little group]6929-the little group . The spoken words seemed to call up a host of words unspoken . There was to [Hadria]211-hadria , a personal as well as a general significance in each sentence , that made [her]211-hadria listen breathlessly for the next . “[3250-you] How would [you]3250-you define [a good woman]3254-a good woman ? ” [she]109-valeria asked . “[3250-you] Precisely as [I]0-i would define [a good man]3255-a good man , ” replied [the Professor]4071-the professor . “[0-i] Oh , [I]0-i think [we]3252-we ask more of [the woman]4547-the woman , ” said [Valeria]109-valeria . “[3252-we] [We]3252-we do indeed ! ” cried [Hadria]211-hadria , with a laugh . “[3252-we] [One]329-one may find [people with a fussy conscience]3258-people with a fussy conscience , a nervous fear of wrong - doing , who are without intelligence and imagination , but [you]3259-you never meet [the noblest , and serenest , and largest examples of goodness without these attributes]3260-the noblest , and serenest , and largest examples of goodness without these attributes , ” said [the Professor]4071-the professor . “[3259-you] This is not the current view of goodness in [women]606-women , ” said [Hadria]211-hadria . “[3259-you] Naturally . The less intelligence and imagination the better , if [our]3252-we current morality is to hold its own . [We]3252-we want [[our]3252-we women]3262-our women to accept its dogmas without question . [We]3252-we tell [them]3262-our women how to be good , and if [they]3262-our women do n't choose to be good in that way , [we]3252-we call [them]3262-our women bad . Nothing could be simpler . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i believe , ” said [Hadria]211-hadria , “[0-i] that [the women who are called good]3263-the women who are called good have much to do with the making of [those that are called bad]3264-those that are called bad . The two kinds are substance and shadow . [We]3252-we shall never get out of the difficulty till [they]3262-our women frankly shake hands , and admit that [they]3262-our women are all playing the same game . ” “[3262-our women] Oh , [they]3262-our women will never do that , ” exclaimed [Valeria]109-valeria , laughing and shaking [her]109-valeria head . “[3262-our women] What madness ! ” “[3262-our women] Why not ? The thing is so obvious . [They]3262-our women are like the two sides of a piece of embroidery : one all smooth and fair , the other rough and ugly , showing the tag ends and the fastenings . But since the embroidery is insisted on , [I]0-i ca n't see that it is of any moral consequence on which side of the canvas one happens to be . ” “[0-i] It is chiefly a matter of luck , ” said [the Professor]4071-the professor . A long shadow fell across [Hadria]211-hadria as [she]0-i spoke , blotting out the little flicker of the sunlight that shone through the stirring leaves . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald had crept up softly across [the lawn]1843-the lawn , and as the chairs were turned towards the flower - borders , [he]181-professor theobald had approached unobserved . [Hadria]211-hadria gave so violent a start when [she]211-hadria heard [his]181-professor theobald voice , that [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue looked at [her]211-hadria anxiously . [He]116-professor fortescue thought [her]211-hadria nerves must be seriously out of order . The feverish manner of [her]211-hadria greeting to [the new - comer]1028-the new - comer , confirmed [his]181-professor theobald fear . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald apologized for intruding . [He]181-professor theobald had given up [his]181-professor theobald intention of going up to [town]4255-town to - day . [He]181-professor theobald meant to put it off till next week . [He]181-professor theobald could not miss [Fortescue]116-professor fortescue 's visit . [One]329-one could not tell when [one]329-one might see [him]181-professor theobald again . And [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald led the conversation airily on ; talking fluently , and at times brilliantly , but always with that indefinable touch of something ignoble , something coarse , that now filled [Hadria]211-hadria with unspeakable dismay . [She]211-hadria was terrified lest [the other two]6938-the other two should go , and [he]181-professor theobald should remain . And yet [she]211-hadria ought to speak frankly to [him]181-professor theobald . [His]181-professor theobald conversation was full of little under - meanings , intended for [her]211-hadria only to understand ; [his]181-professor theobald look , [his]181-professor theobald manner to [her]211-hadria made [her]211-hadria actually hate [him]181-professor theobald . Yet [she]211-hadria felt the utter inconsequence and injustice of [her]211-hadria attitude . [He]181-professor theobald had not changed . There was nothing new in [him]181-professor theobald . The change was in [herself]211-hadria . [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue had awakened [her]211-hadria . But , of course , [he]181-professor theobald was [one in ten thousand]6939-one in ten thousand . It was not fair to make the comparison by which [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald suffered so pitiably . At that moment , as if [Fate]102-fate had intended to prove to [her]211-hadria how badly [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald really stood comparison with [any thoroughly well - bred man]6940-any thoroughly well - bred man , even if infinitely beneath [him]181-professor theobald intellectually , [Joseph Fleming]159-joseph fleming happened to call . [He]181-professor theobald was [his]181-professor theobald old self again , simple , friendly , contented . [Theobald]181-professor theobald was in one of [his]181-professor theobald self - satisfied moods . Perhaps [he]181-professor theobald enjoyed the triumph of [his]181-professor theobald position in regard to [Hadria]211-hadria . At any rate , [he]181-professor theobald seemed to pounce on [the new - comer]1028-the new - comer as a foil to [his]181-professor theobald own brilliancy . [Joseph]159-joseph fleming had no talent to oppose to it , but [he]159-joseph fleming had a simple dignity , the offspring of a kind and generous nature , which made [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald 's conduct towards [him]159-joseph fleming appear contemptible . [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue shifted uncomfortably in [his]116-professor fortescue chair . [Hadria]211-hadria tried to change the topic ; the flush deepening in [her]211-hadria cheeks . [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue attempted to come to [her]211-hadria aid . [Joseph Fleming]159-joseph fleming laughed good - naturedly . [They]6942-they sat late into the evening . [Theobald]181-professor theobald could not find an excuse to outstay [[his]181-professor theobald colleague]1971-his colleague , since [they]6942-they were [both guests at [the same house]6945-the same house]6944-both guests at the same house . “[0-i] [I]0-i must see [you]3265-you alone some time to - morrow , ” [he]181-professor theobald managed to whisper . There - was no time for a reply . “[0-i] [I]0-i shall go and rest before dinner , ” said [Valeria]109-valeria . [Hadria]211-hadria went into [the house]296-the house by the open window of [the drawing - room]737-the drawing - room . [She]211-hadria sank back on the sofa ; a blackness came before [her]211-hadria eyes . “[0-i] No , no , [I]0-i wo n't , [I]0-i wo n't . Let [me]0-i learn not to let things overpower [me]0-i , in future . ” When [Valeria]109-valeria entered , dressed for dinner , [she]109-valeria found [Hadria]211-hadria , deadly pale , standing against the sofa , whose arm [she]211-hadria was grasping with both hands , as if for dear life . [Valeria]109-valeria rushed forward . “[0-i] Good heavens , [Hadria]211-hadria ! are [you]211-hadria going to faint ? ” “[211-hadria] No , ” said [Hadria]211-hadria , “[211-hadria] [I]0-i am not going to faint , if there is such a thing as human will . ” THE morning had passed as usual , but household arrangements at [the Cottage]1763-the cottage had required much adjustment , [one of [the maids]6950-the maids]6949-one of the maids being ill . [She]6949-one of the maids had been sent away for a rest , and the difficulty was to find another . [Mary]128-mary went from [the Red House]4718-the red house as substitute , in the mean time , and [the Red House]4718-the red house became disorganised . “[211-hadria] [You]211-hadria look distracted with these little worries , [Hadria]211-hadria . [I]0-i should have said that some desperate crisis was hanging over [you]211-hadria , instead of merely a domestic disturbance . ” [Valeria]109-valeria was established on [the lawn]1843-the lawn , with a book . “[0-i] [I]0-i am going to seek serenity in [the churchyard]1413-the churchyard , ” explained [Hadria]211-hadria . “[0-i] But [I]0-i thought [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald said something about calling . ” “[181-professor theobald] [I]0-i leave [you]211-hadria to entertain [him]181-professor theobald , if [he]181-professor theobald comes , ” [Hadria]211-hadria returned , and hastened away . [She]211-hadria stopped at [[Martha]129-martha 's cottage]6954-martha 's cottage for [the child]4983-the child . Ah ! What would become of [her]211-hadria if it were not for [Martha]129-martha ? [The two]4880-the two sauntered together along [the Craddock road]6957-the craddock road . All night long , [Hadria]211-hadria had been trying to decide when and how to speak to [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald . Should [she]211-hadria send for [him]181-professor theobald ? Should [she]211-hadria write to [him]181-professor theobald ? Should [she]211-hadria trust to chance for an opportunity of speaking ? But , no , [she]211-hadria could not endure to see [him]181-professor theobald again in the presence of [others]432-others , before [she]211-hadria had spoken ! [Yesterday]282-yesterday 's experience had been too terrible . [She]211-hadria had brought pencil and paper with [her]211-hadria , in order to be able to write to [him]181-professor theobald , if [she]211-hadria decided on that course . There were plenty of retired nooks under the shade of the yew - trees in [the churchyard]1413-the churchyard , where [one]329-one could write . The thick hedges made [it]1413-the churchyard perfectly secluded , and at this hour , it was always solitary . [Little Martha]129-martha was gathering wild - flowers in the hedges . [She]211-hadria used to pluck them to lay on [[[her]129-martha mother]520-her mother 's grave]6962-her mother 's grave . [She]211-hadria had but a vague idea of [that unknown mother]6963-that unknown mother , but [Hadria]211-hadria had tried to make [the dead woman]6964-the dead woman live again , in [the child]4983-the child 's mind , as a gentle and tender image . The little offering was made each time that [they]6966-they took [their]6966-they walk in [the direction of [Craddock]23-craddock]6967-the direction of craddock . [The grave]4790-the grave looked fresh and sweet in the summer sunshine , with the ivy creeping up the tomb - stone and half obliterating the name . A rose - tree that [Hadria]211-hadria and [Martha]129-martha had planted together , was laden with rich red blooms . [The two figures]450-the two figures stood , hand in hand , by [the grave]4790-the grave . [The child]4983-the child stooped to place [her]4983-the child little tribute of flowers at the head of the green mound . [Neither of [them]450-the two figures]6546-neither of them noticed [a tall figure at the wicket gate]6973-a tall figure at the wicket gate . [He]6973-a tall figure at the wicket gate stood outside , looking up [the path]3883-the path , absolutely motionless . [Martha]129-martha let go [Hadria]211-hadria 's hand , and ran off after a gorgeous butterfly that had fluttered over the headstone : a symbol of the soul ; fragile , beautiful , helpless thing that any rough hand may crush and ruin . [Hadria]211-hadria turned to watch the graceful , joyous movement of [the child]4983-the child , and [her]211-hadria delight in the beauty of the rich brown wings , with their enamelled spots of sapphire . “[211-hadria] [Hadria]211-hadria ! ” [She]4983-the child gave a little gasping cry , and turned sharply . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald looked at [her]4983-the child with an intent , triumphant expression . [She]4983-the child stood before [him]181-professor theobald , for the moment , as if paralysed . It was by no means the first time that this look had crossed [his]181-professor theobald face , but [she]4983-the child had been blind , and had not fully understood it . [He]181-professor theobald interpreted [her]4983-the child cry and [her]4983-the child paleness , as signs of the fullness of [his]181-professor theobald power over [her]4983-the child . This pleased [him]181-professor theobald immeasurably . [His]181-professor theobald self - love basked and purred . [He]181-professor theobald felt that [his]181-professor theobald moment of triumph had come . Contrasting this meeting with the last occasion when [they]6976-they had stood together beside [this grave]5597-this grave , had [he]181-professor theobald not ground for self - applause ? [He]181-professor theobald remembered so well that unpleasant episode . It was [Hadria]211-hadria who stood then in the more powerful position . [He]181-professor theobald had actually feared to meet [her]211-hadria eye . [He]181-professor theobald remembered how bitterly [she]4983-the child had spoken , of [her]4983-the child passion for revenge , of the relentless feud between [man]332-man and [woman]3844-woman . [They]6976-they had discussed the question of vengeance ; [he]181-professor theobald had pointed out its futility , and [Hadria]211-hadria had set [her]211-hadria teeth and desired it none the less . [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton had reminded [her]4983-the child of [a woman]3753-a woman 's helplessness if [she]4983-the child places [herself]4983-the child in opposition to [a man]3704-a man , for whom all things are ordered in the society that [he]181-professor theobald governs ; [her]4983-the child only chance of striking a telling blow being through [his]181-professor theobald passions . If [he]181-professor theobald were in love with [her]4983-the child , then there might be some hope of making [him]181-professor theobald wince . And [Hadria]211-hadria , with a fierce swiftness had accepted the condition , with a mixture of confidence in [her]211-hadria own power of rousing emotion , if [she]211-hadria willed , and of scorn for the creature who could be appealed to through [his]181-professor theobald passions , but not through [his]181-professor theobald sense of justice . That [she]211-hadria might [herself]211-hadria be in that vulnerable condition , had not appeared to strike [her]211-hadria as possible . It was a challenge that [he]181-professor theobald could not but accept . [She]211-hadria attracted [him]181-professor theobald irresistibly . From the first moment of meeting , [he]181-professor theobald had felt [her]211-hadria power , and recognized , at the same time , the strange spirit of enmity that [she]211-hadria seemed to feel towards [him]181-professor theobald , and to arouse in [him]181-professor theobald against [her]211-hadria . [He]181-professor theobald felt the savage in [him]181-professor theobald awake , the desire of mere conquest . Long had [he]181-professor theobald waited and watched , and at last [he]181-professor theobald had seen [her]211-hadria flush and tremble at [his]181-professor theobald approach ; and as if to make [his]181-professor theobald victory more complete and insolent , it was at this grave that [she]211-hadria was to confess [herself]211-hadria ready to lose [the world]334-the world for [his]181-professor theobald sake ! Yes ; and [she]211-hadria should understand the position of affairs to the full , and consent nevertheless ! [Her]211-hadria adoption of [the child]4983-the child had added to [his]181-professor theobald triumph . [He]181-professor theobald could not think of it without a sense of something humourous in the relation of events . If ever Fate was ironical , this was the occasion ! [He]181-professor theobald felt so sure of [Hadria]211-hadria to - day , that [he]181-professor theobald was swayed by an overpowering temptation to reveal to [her]211-hadria the almost comic situation . It appealed to [his]181-professor theobald sense of the absurd , and to the savagery that lurked , like a beast of prey , at the foundation of [his]181-professor theobald nature . [Her]211-hadria evident emotion when [he]181-professor theobald arrived yesterday afternoon and all through [his]181-professor theobald visit , [her]211-hadria agitation to - day , at the mere sound of [his]181-professor theobald voice , assured [him]181-professor theobald that [his]181-professor theobald hold over [her]211-hadria was secure . [He]181-professor theobald must be [a fool]1606-a fool indeed if [he]181-professor theobald could not keep it , in spite of revelations . To offer [himself]181-professor theobald to [her]211-hadria threatened vengeance of [his]181-professor theobald own accord , and to see [her]211-hadria turned away disarmed , because [she]211-hadria loved [him]181-professor theobald ; that would be the climax of [his]181-professor theobald victory ! There was something of [their]6985-their old antagonism , in the attitude in which [they]6985-their stood facing [one another]3945-one another by the side of [the grave]4790-the grave , looking straight into [one another]3945-one another 's eyes . The sound of [the child]4983-the child 's happy laughter floated back to [them]6985-their across the spot where [its mother]755-its mother lay at rest . Whether [Theobald]181-professor theobald 's intense consciousness of the situation had , in some way , affected [Hadria]211-hadria , or whether [his]181-professor theobald expression had given a clue , it would be difficult to say , but suddenly , as a whiff of scent invades the senses , [she]211-hadria became aware of a new and horrible fact which had wandered into [her]211-hadria mind , [she]211-hadria knew not how ; and [she]211-hadria took a step backwards , as if stunned , breathing shortly and quickly . Again [he]181-professor theobald interpreted this as a sign of intense feeling . “[211-hadria] [Hadria]211-hadria , ” [he]181-professor theobald said bending towards [her]211-hadria , “[211-hadria] [you]211-hadria do love [me]0-i ? ” [He]181-professor theobald did not wait for [her]211-hadria answer , so confident did [he]181-professor theobald feel . “[211-hadria] [You]211-hadria love [me]0-i for [myself]0-i , not for [my]0-i virtues or qualities , for [I]0-i have but few of those , alas ! ” [She]211-hadria tried to speak , but [he]181-professor theobald interrupted [her]211-hadria . “[0-i] [I]0-i want to make a confession to [you]211-hadria . [I]0-i can never forget what [you]211-hadria said that day of [Marion Fenwick]273-marion fenwick 's wedding , at the side of [this very grave]3267-this very grave ; [you]211-hadria said that [you]211-hadria wanted to take vengeance on [the man who had brought such misery to [this poor woman]5605-this poor woman]3268-the man who had brought such misery to this poor woman . [You]211-hadria threatened — at least , it amounted to a threat — to make [him]3268-the man who had brought such misery to this poor woman fall in love with [you]211-hadria , if ever [you]211-hadria should meet [him]3268-the man who had brought such misery to this poor woman , and to render [him]3268-the man who had brought such misery to this poor woman miserable through [his]3268-the man who had brought such misery to this poor woman passion . [I]0-i loved [you]211-hadria and [I]0-i trembled , but [I]0-i thought to [myself]0-i , ‘ What if [I]0-i could make [her]5605-this poor woman return [my]0-i love ? Where would the vengeance be then ? ’ ” [Hadria]211-hadria had remained , for a second , perfectly still , and then turned abruptly away . “[0-i] [I]0-i knew it would be a shock to [you]211-hadria . [I]0-i did not dare to tell [you]211-hadria before . Think what depended on it for [me]0-i . Had [I]0-i told [you]211-hadria at that moment , [I]0-i knew all hope for [me]0-i would be at an end . But now , it seems to [me]0-i [my]0-i duty to tell [you]211-hadria . If [you]211-hadria wish for vengeance still , here [I]0-i am at [your]211-hadria mercy — take it . ” [He]6991-he stretched out [his]6991-he arms and stood waiting before [her]211-hadria . But [she]211-hadria was silent . [He]6991-he was not surprised . Such a revelation , at such a moment , must , of necessity , stun [her]211-hadria . “[211-hadria] [Hadria]211-hadria , pronounce [my]0-i fate . Do [you]211-hadria wish for vengeance still ? [You]211-hadria have only to take it , if [you]211-hadria do . Only for heaven 's sake , do n't keep [me]0-i in suspense . Tell [me]0-i [your]211-hadria decision . ” Still silence . “[211-hadria] Do [you]211-hadria want to take revenge on [me]0-i now ? ” [he]6991-he repeated . “[211-hadria] No ; ” [she]211-hadria said abruptly , “[211-hadria] of what use would it be ? No , no , wait , wait a moment . [I]0-i want no vengeance . It is useless for [women]606-women to try to fight against [men]3698-men ; [they]606-women can only hate [them]606-women ! ” [The Professor]4071-the professor started , as if [he]6991-he had been struck . [They]6993-they stood looking at [one another]3945-one another . “[606-women] In [heaven]4276-heaven 's name , what is the meaning of this ? Am [I]0-i to be hated for a sin committed years ago , and long since repented ? Have [you]211-hadria no breadth of sympathy , no tolerance for erring humanity ? Am [I]0-i never to be forgiven ? Oh , [Hadria]211-hadria , [Hadria]211-hadria , this is more than [I]0-i can bear ! ” [She]0-i was standing very still and very calm . [Her]0-i tones were clear and deliberate . “[211-hadria] If vengeance is futile , so is forgiveness . It undoes no wrong . It is not a question of forgiveness or of vengeance . [I]0-i think , after all , if [I]0-i were to attempt the impossible by trying to avenge [women whom [men]3698-men have injured]3273-women whom men have injured , [I]0-i should begin with [the wives]3275-the wives . In this case ” ( [she]0-i turned to the grave ) , “[3275-the wives] the tragedy is more obvious , but [I]0-i believe the everyday tragedy of [the docile wife]3276-the docile wife and [mother]3851-mother is even more profound . ” “[211-hadria] [You]211-hadria speak as coldly , as bitterly , as if [you]211-hadria regarded [me]0-i as [[your]211-hadria worst enemy]3278-your worst enemy — [I]0-i who love [you]211-hadria . ” [He]3698-men came forward a step , and [she]0-i drew back hurriedly . “[211-hadria] All that is over . [I]0-i too have a confession to make . ” “[0-i] Good heavens , what is it ? Are [you]211-hadria not what [I]0-i thought [you]211-hadria ? Have [you]211-hadria some history , some stain — ? Do n't for pity 's sake tell [me]0-i that ! ” [Hadria]211-hadria looked at [him]3698-men , with a cold miserable smile . “[0-i] That is really amusing ! ” [she]0-i cried ; “[0-i] [I]0-i should not hold [myself]0-i responsible to [you]211-hadria , for [my]0-i past , in any case . [My]0-i confession relates to the present . [I]0-i came up here with this pencil and paper , half resolved to write to [you]211-hadria — [I]0-i wanted to tell [you]211-hadria that — that [I]0-i find — [I]0-i find [my]0-i feelings towards [you]211-hadria have changed — ” [He]6995-he gave a hoarse , inarticulate cry , and turned sharply round . [His]6995-he hands went up to [his]6995-he head . Then [he]6995-he veered suddenly , and went fiercely up to [her]211-hadria . “[0-i] Then [you]211-hadria are in earnest ? [You]211-hadria do hate [me]0-i ! for a sin dead and buried ? Good God ! could one have believed it ? Because [I]0-i was honest with [you]211-hadria , where [another man]6851-another man would have kept the matter dark , [I]0-i am to be thrown over without a word , without a chance . [Lord]3280-lord , and this is what [a woman]3753-a woman calls love ! ” [He]6995-he broke into a laugh that sounded ghastly and cruel , in the serene calm of [the churchyard]1413-the churchyard . The laugh seemed to get the better of [him]6995-he . [He]6995-he had lost self - control . [He]6995-he put [his]6995-he hands on [his]6995-he hips and went on laughing harshly , yet sometimes with a real mirth , as if by that means only could [he]6995-he express the fierce emotions that had been roused in [him]6995-he . Mortified and furious as [he]6995-he was , [he]6995-he derived genuine and cynical amusement from the incident . “[3753-a woman] And the devotion that [we]3282-we have professed — think of it ! and the union of [souls]2093-souls — ha , ha , ha ! and the common interests and the deep sympathy — it is screaming ! Almost worth the price [I]0-i pay , for the sake of the rattling good joke ! And by [this grave]5597-this grave ! Great heavens , how humorous is destiny ! ” [He]6995-he leant [his]6995-he arms on the tombstone and laughed on softly , [his]6995-he big form shaking , [his]6995-he strange sinister face appearing over the stone , irradiated with merriment . In the dusk , among [the graves]4627-the graves , the grinning face looked like that of some mocking demon , some gargoyle come to life , to cast a spell of evil over the place . “[0-i] Ah , [me]0-i , life has its comic moments ! ” [His]6995-he eyes were streaming . “[0-i] [I]0-i fear [I]0-i must seem to [you]3285-you flippant , but [you]3285-you will admit the ludicrous side of the situation . [I]0-i am none the less ready to cut [my]0-i throat — ha , ha , ha ! Admit , [[my]0-i dear]3722-my dear [Hadria]211-hadria — [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley — that it appeals also to [your]3285-you sense of humour . A common sense of humour , [you]3285-you know , was one of [our]3287-our bonds of union . What more appropriate than that [we]3287-our should part with shaking sides ? Oh , [Lord]3288-lord ! oh , [Lord]3289-lord ! what am [I]0-i to do ? One ca n't live on a good joke for ever . ” [He]6995-he grasped [his]6995-he head in [his]6995-he hands ; then suddenly , [he]6995-he broke out into another paroxysm . “[3289-lord] The feminine nature always the same , always , always ; infinitely charming and infinitely volatile . Delicious , and oh how instructive ! ” [He]6995-he slowly recovered calmness , and remained leaning on the gravestone . “[3288-lord] May [I]0-i ask when this little change began to occur ! ” [he]6995-he asked presently . “[0-i] If [you]3285-you will ask in a less insolent fashion . ” [He]6995-he drew [himself]6995-he up from [his]6995-he leaning attitude , and repeated the question , in different words . [Hadria]211-hadria answered it , briefly . “[0-i] Oh , [I]0-i see , ” [he]6995-he said , the savage gleam coming back to [his]6995-he eyes . “[0-i] The change in [your]3285-you feelings began when [Fortescue]116-professor fortescue appeared ? ” [Hadria]211-hadria flushed . “[116-professor fortescue] It was when [he]116-professor fortescue appeared that [I]0-i became definitely aware of that which [I]0-i had been struggling with all [my]0-i might and main to hide from [myself]0-i , for a long time . ” “[0-i] And that was — ? ” “[0-i] That there was something in [you]3285-you that made [me]0-i — well , why should [I]0-i not say it?—that made [me]0-i shrink . ” [He]6995-he set [his]6995-he lips . “[3285-you] [You]3285-you have not mentioned the mysterious something . ” “[3285-you] An element that [I]0-i have been conscious of from the first day [I]0-i saw [you]3285-you . ” Something that [I]0-i had , and [Fortescue]116-professor fortescue had not , it would seem . ”[0-i] “ Yes . ”[3285-you] “ And so , on account of this diaphanous , indescribable , exquisite something , [I]3285-you am to be calmly thrown over ; calmly told to go about [my]3285-you business ! ”[3285-you] [He]3285-you began to walk up and down [the pathway]454-the pathway , with feverish steps , talking rapidly , and representing [Hadria]211-hadria 's conduct in different lights , each one making it appear more absurd and more unjust than the last . “ [I]211-hadria have no defence to make , ”[211-hadria] [she]211-hadria said , “ [I]211-hadria know [I]211-hadria have behaved contemptibly ; self - deception is no excuse . [I]211-hadria can explain but not justify [myself]211-hadria . [I]211-hadria wanted to escape from [my]211-hadria eternal self ; [I]211-hadria was tired of fighting and always in vain . [I]211-hadria wanted to throw [myself]211-hadria into the life and hopes of [somebody else]6262-somebody else , [somebody who had some chance of a real and effective existence]6999-somebody who had some chance of a real and effective existence . Then other elements of attraction and temptation came ; [your]7000-you own memory will tell how many there were . [You]7000-you knew so well how to surround [me]211-hadria with these . Everything conspired to tempt [me]211-hadria . It seemed as if , in [you]7000-you , [I]211-hadria had found a refuge from [myself]211-hadria . [You]7000-you have no little power over the emotions , as [you]7000-you are aware . [My]211-hadria feeling has been genuine , heaven knows ! but , always , always , through it all , [I]211-hadria have been aware of this element that repels [me]211-hadria ; and [I]211-hadria have distrusted [you]7000-you . ”[211-hadria] “ [I]3291-he knew [you]7000-you distrusted [me]3291-he , ”[3291-he] [he]3291-he said gloomily . “ It is useless to say [I]3291-he bitterly regret it all . Naturally , [I]3291-he regret it far more bitterly than [you]7000-you can do . And if [my]3291-he conduct towards [you]7000-you rankles in [your]7000-you heart , [you]7000-you can remember that [I]3291-he have to contend with what is far worse than any sense of being badly treated : the sense of having treated [someone]4160-someone badly . ”[3291-he] [He]3291-he walked up and down , with bent head and furrowed brows . [He]3291-he looked like some restless wild animal pacing its cage . Intense mortification gave [him]3291-he a strange , malicious expression . [He]3291-he seemed to be casting about for a means of returning the stunning blow that [he]3291-he had received , just at the moment of expected triumph . “ Damn ! ”[3291-he] [he]3291-he exclaimed with sudden vehemence , and stood still , looking down into [Hadria]211-hadria 's face , with cruel , glittering eyes . [He]3291-he glanced furtively around . There was [no one in sight]3292-no one in sight . Even [little Martha]129-martha was making mud - pies by [the church]1115-the church door . The thick yew trees shut in [the churchyard]1413-the churchyard from [the village]1124-the village . There was not a sound , far or near , to break the sense of seclusion . “ And [you]3291-he mean to tell [me]129-martha [we]7002-we are to part ? [You]3291-he mean to tell [me]129-martha that this is [your]3291-he final decision ? ”[129-martha] [She]129-martha bowed [her]129-martha head .
